loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Repair Automobile

loans.name: Marble

texts.en:
Marble is 40 years of age and a single mother of five children aged between 10 and 20 years. All her children go to school. The family owns and resides in a two roomed house where she stays with eight people. She takes care of additional family members.

The family has access to electricity but do not have piped water at home.  The family has three meals a day.  Her greatest monthly expenses includes paying utility bills, school fees for children, medication and feeding the family.

Marble sells passion fruit juice in Kawempe market. She works seven days a week. She receives an average of 40 customers a day. She has done this business for over twelve years.  Her main challenges are seasonality and the rainy season because she works from a muddy place.  She sells on a retail basis only.

She has been with MCDT for eight years and is servicing her seventh loan, working with the same group mates all this time. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of passion fruit. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and to own and start distributing to different shops.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of passion fruit

loans.name: Makhmadnazar

texts.ru: Темуров Махмадназар проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст, 62 года. Вдовец, имеет 6 детей. Темуров Махмадназар перевозкой занимается более 16 лет. Он превозит на своем грузовике. Кредит берет для ремонта автомашины, чтобы предоставить безопасную услугу.
texts.en:
Makhmadnazar T. lives in close to Hamadoni, Tajikistan. He is sixty-two years old and a widower with six children. Makhmadnazar T. has been in transportation for over sixteen years. He uses his truck for deliveries. He is asking for a loan to repair his truck in order to provide continuous service.

Translated from Russian by Susan Savkov, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repair Automobile

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This borrower is 37 years old and married. He completed primary school and passed the exam. 

He owns a photography shop and has been working for a long period in this field. He is using this loan to expand his shop and buy merchandise, such as cameras and photographic supplies. 

He has benefited from the loan. He has one employee, but in the coming days, he intends to hire another employee to help him. His income has increased and he has acquired a great deal of experience and skills in his field. He has a good reputation among his friends in the market.

loans.use: To buy cameras and photo supplies

loans.name: Wasswa 2 Jane Nakikyo Group

texts.en:
Jane N. is a business woman who is fifty years old, married and blessed with five children.  She is more so blessed by having eight dependents, of whom four are in school.

She has been carrying out her poultry business for five years so far. She is using the loan to purchase poultry items such as poultry feed, drugs, chicks, and so forth. She is a hardworking business woman whose dream is to educate her siblings.

loans.use: To purchase poultry items such as poultry feeds, drugs, chicks, and so forth.

loans.name: Zaituni

texts.en:
Zaituni is 37 years of age, married with four children aged between 13 and 19 years. All her children go to school. The family resides in and owns a six roomed house where she stays with six people. She takes care of additional family members.

The family has access to electricity but has no piped water at home.  The family has three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses include paying utility bills, school fees for the children, medication and feeding the family.

Zaituni owns a restaurant in Kisaasi selling all types of food ranging from traditional to western food. She works seven days a week. She receives an average of 50 customers a day. She has had this business for over ten years. She incurs transport costs to and from different markets buying foodstuffs.

Her main challenges are seasonality and the rainy season because she works from a muddy place.  She sells on a retail basis only.  She has been with MCDT for ten years and is servicing her twentieth loan, working with the same group mates all this time. She wants to use this loan to buy more foodstuffs like bunches of bananas, beef and also charcoal. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and own and start doing outside catering.

loans.use: To buy bunches of bananas, beef and charcoal

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is 50 years of age and a single mother of five children aged between 10 and 20 years. All her children go to school. The family resides and rents a one roomed house where she stays with eight people. She takes care of additional family members.  The family has access to electricity and no piped water at home.  The family has three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses includes paying utility bills, school fees for children and medication and feeding the family. 

Joyce sells milk in the Mulago market. She works seven days a week. Joyce receives an average of 40 customers a day. She has done this business for over twelve years She incurs transport costs to and from buying milk from Katwe. Her main challenge is the rainy season because she works from a muddy place.  She sells on retail basis only. 

Joyce has been with MCDT for five years and is servicing her tenth loan with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more jerrycans of milk . She aspires to her business grow bigger and someday start selling wholesale only
.

loans.use: To buy more jerrycans of milk

loans.name: Latifa Lutale ‘S Group

texts.en:
Latifa is 40 years of age, widowed and has twelve children aged between 13 and 19 years. All of her children go to school. The family resides and rents a two roomed house where she stays with six people. She takes care of additional family members.  The family has access to electricity and no piped water at home.  The family has three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses include paying utility bills, school fees for children and medication and feeding the family. 

Latifa owns a restaurant in Katanga  selling all types of snacks like chips, chicken, fish, and sausages. She works seven days a week. She receives an average of 50 customers a day. Latifa has done this business for over ten years. She incurs transport costs to and from buying food supplies from different markets. Her main challenges are seasonality and the rainy season because she works from a muddy place.  She sells on retail basis only.

Latifa has been with MCDT for four years, servicing her fifth loan with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more food supplies like sacks of Irish potatoes, cooking fish, and packets of sausages. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and start doing outside catering.
.

loans.use: To  buy sacks of Irish potatoes, cooking oil and packets of sausages

loans.name: Faith  Nalumansi  ‘S Group

texts.en:
Faith is 31 years of age and married with two children, aged between 5 and 7 years. All her children go to school. The family resides and rents a two roomed house where she stays with four people. She takes care of additional family members.  The family has access to electricity and no piped water at home.  The family has three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses include paying utility bills, school fees for children and medication and feeding the family. 

Faith owns a stall selling second hand clothes in Ntinda. She works seven days a week and receives an average of 10 customers a day. She has done this business for over ten years. She incurs transport costs to and from buying clothes from the Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda. Her main challenges are seasonality and transportation of clothes from Owino market to her place of work in Ntinda.  She sells on retail basis only. Faith has been with MCDT for four years and is servicing her fifth loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second hand clothes. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and start importing clothes herself.
.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second hand clothes

loans.name: Nsambya V Mukiibi Madina Group

texts.en: M. Madina is a business, thirty-seven years old, single and blessed with four children of whom three attend school. She also has two dependents attending school. She is a group leader of five group members. M. is deals in the tomato business and she has been selling for over four years. She is using the loan to purchase items such as baskets of tomatoes from far away villages to sell in the market place. She is a hardworking business woman whose dream is to educate her children and improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase items such as baskets of tomatoes from far away villages to sell.

loans.name: Wasswa 1 Lwaga Joyce Group

texts.en: Joyce L. is a widow of forty-six years old and blessed with four school-aged children. She also has ten dependents of which six of them are going to school. She is carrys out tailoring services and has done this for two years. She is using the loan to purchase clothing and cloth to make wears. She is an active woman and dreams of building a better house for her family.

loans.use: To purchase clothing and cloth to make wears.

loans.name: Wasswa 1 Penina Sebuliba Group

texts.en:
Penina S. is a hardworking business woman and married with four school-aged children. She has operated a tailoring business for over twenty years. 

Penina is using the loan to purchase items like fabrics and cloth for making designed clothing and other items for her clients. She is a hardworking business woman whose dream is to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase items like fabric and cloth for making designed clothing and other items for her clients

loans.name: Ailyn

texts.en:
With three children, Ailyn A. doesn’t know anymore how she will budget their small income. Her husband works as a farmer and she is helping him  maintain the rice field. She is currently preparing her farm for planting and she is needing help to be able improve their harvest. 

She would like to apply for a loan of Php 6,000 at Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Salama 2 Naigaga Merab Group

texts.en:
N. Merab is forty-eight years old and is married with six children and three siblings schooling.

Merab has been in a bakery business for over twenty years. She is using the loan to purchase bakery ingredients like milk, wheat flour, baking powder, sugar, etc., to expand her business.

Merab is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase bakery ingredients to expand her business

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is 28 years of age and is married with three children aged between 3 and 7 years. The family resides in and rents a two-roomed house where she lives with five people. She also takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water at home. The family has three meals a day.

Rebecca owns a stall in Makerere Kikoni selling different types of cosmetics on a retail basis only. She has operated this business for over ten years and works seven days a week. She receives an average of twenty customers a day. 

Rebecca incurs transport costs to and from buying cosmetics from shops in Kikuubo, one of the busiest places in Uganda. Her main challenges are seasonality and transportation of cosmetics from shops in Kikuubo to her place of work. Her greatest monthly expenses include paying utility bills, medication and feeding the family.

Rebecca has been with MCDT for two years and is servicing her fourth loan, working all this time with the same group members. She wants to use this loan to buy more boxes of cosmetics.

Rebecca is aspiring to see her business grow bigger and to start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of cosmetics

loans.name: Janette

texts.en:
Janette, 31, spends much of her time managing her rice farming business. She also has a sari-sari store as an additional source of income. She enjoys working on the farm and in the store because it provides for food, shelter, and clothing of her family.  She is married to Hilario and they have 5 children.  

She would like to continue working on her farm to help feed her family but she is limited with financing the business.  That’s why she joined the  Community Economic Ventures, Inc., to be able to avail herdelf to a loan that would improve her business.  She requested a loan of 15,000 Php, enough to buy groceries and supplies that she needs for the farm.

loans.use: To buy supplies of groceries and farm supplies

loans.name: Izro

texts.en:
Izro, 41, lives in Banga, South Cotabato and has a rice-farming business. He devotes his time to working in his rice field.

Izro heard about Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and that it offers financial support to entrepreneurs like him, and he later joined in October 2008.

Izro’s business is continually growing and now he is requesting a loan of 6,000 Php. This loan has a low interest rate and will be helpful to sustain his business.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria is the mother of eight children and has been able to sustain her family through rice farming. She is 53 years old and lives in Norala, South Cotabato. The income she receives sends her children to school and provides for the basic needs of her family.

Victoria would like a loan to help support her business. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and is requesting a loan of Php 15,000 which will enable her to purchase fertilizer and other farm needs.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida, 42 years old, is a rice farmer. She is able to earn income from her small farm, which she uses to buy her family food, clothing and other basic needs. Her 1-hectare (2.5-acre) rice field is located in Norala, South Cotabato.

Zenaida would like to apply for a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to fund her farm and buy farming necessities.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
Dolores is 41 years old, living in Banga, South Cotabato. She has a hog raising and rice farming business. She owns 2 hectares of rice field and has 12 piglets and one sow. She is the mother of four children (her eldest is  21 years old). She makes enough money for her family when she has a good harvest from the farm.

Dolores would like a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to purchase farm inputs. This will be very helpful to sustain her family and business.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Consolidad

texts.en:
60-year-old Consolidad is married and has five children. She’s managing a 1-hectare (2.5-acre) corn field in Banga, South Cotabato and also has a half-hectare (1.25-acre) guava field on which she makes a weekly harvest.

Consolidad needs additional capital to purchase farm supplies so she’s requesting a loan of Php 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. CEVI offers the lowest interest rate and the loan would be of great help in financing Consolidad’s business.

loans.use: To buy seed and other farm supplies

loans.name: Carmen

texts.en:
Carmen, 61, spends much time managing her rice farming business. She enjoys working on the farm because it provides for the food, shelter, and clothing of her family. Helen is married to Bonifacio and they have five children.

She would like to continue working on her farm for the sustenance of her family and so joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to be able to avail a loan intended for her business. She is now requesting a loan of 15,000 Php to buy materials and supplies she needs for the farm

loans.use: Farm inputs

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida is 45 years old and lives in Banga, South Cotabato. She has businesses in rice farming and a sari-sari (general) store. Now, with all her efforts to improve her businesses, she is able to provide for the financial needs of her two children including sending them to school.

Aida needs additional capital of Php 10,000 as a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She will use the loan to buy groceries for her store and farm supplies to make her farm more productive.

loans.use: To buy groceries for her store and farm supplies

loans.name: Felipe

texts.en: Felipe is 56 years old from Banga, South Cotabato. He manages a 1 hectare rice field. The harvest is the main source of his income which is very helpful to sustain his family. He has joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and asks for a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos. It will be very helpful for him to buy farm necessities and to be able to finance his business with a lower interest rate from CEVI.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and farm supplies

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.en:
Bernadette, 41, is a rice farmer, managing a rice field in Banga, South Cotabato. She works hard in order to have a good harvest so as to support her family of five children, the eldest being 20 years old.

Bernadette is limited in her capital and that’s why she joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to obtain a loan. She’s requesting 10,000 Php to support her business by buying fertilizer and other farm materials.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Eric

texts.en: Eric, 31 years old, manages a 1 hectare rice field in Banga, South Cotabato. He’s married and has a 5-year old child. He needs additional capital to purchase farm supplies and fertilizers. He’s requesting a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. for 15,000 Philippine pesos. CEVI offers the lowest interest rate and the loan will be of great help in financing his business.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebbecca is 30 years of age and is married with three children aged between 3 and 7 years. The family resides in and rents a two-roomed house where she lives with five people. She also takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water at home. The family has three meals a day.

Rebbecca owns a stall selling bricks in Kisaasi Kikoni. She has operated this business for over ten years and works seven days a week. She receives an average of twenty customers a day, selling wholesale only.

Rebbecca incurs transport costs to and from buying bricks and half-bricks from the village of Kulambiro. Her main challenges are seasonality and transportation. Her greatest monthly expenses include paying utility bills, medication and feeding the family.

Rebbecca has been with MCDT for one year and is servicing her third loan, working all this time with the same group members. She wants to use this loan to buy more bricks.

Rebbecca is aspiring to seeing her business grow bigger and to owning a business laying bricks herself.

loans.use: To buy more half-bricks to sell

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
56-year-old Delia manages a 2-hectare (5-acre) farm in Banga, South Cotabato. She has twelve children and the eldest is 33 years old.

Delia started her business in 1975 using land from their parents. She was able to plant it with calamansi (a citrus fruit), coconut trees, bananas, rice and corn.

In October 2008, Delia joined CEVI and now she’s requesting a loan of Php 10,000 to help finance her business. The income she will receive is very helpful in providing their basic needs.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and farm supplies

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Rice farming is the main source of living of Anita, 61 years old. She manages a rice field in Banga, South Cotabato. She has eight children in the family to support and needs financial support for her business.

Anita joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and requests a loan of Php 15,000 which she will use to purchase farm inputs. This way the basic needs of her family will be met.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Beatrice  Adongo's Group

texts.en:
Beatrice is 24 years of age, single, with no children She and her family reside in and rent a two-roomed house where Beatrice stays with five people. She takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water at home. The family gets three meals a day.

Beatrice's greatest monthly expenses include paying utility bills, medication, and feeding the family. Beatrice owns a stall selling second-hand clothes in Nakawa. She works seven days a week. She receives an average of 10 customers a day. She has done this business for over ten years. She incurs transport costs to and from buying clothes from Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda. Her main challenges are seasonality and transportation of clothes from Owino market to her place of work in Nakawa

Beatrice sells on a retail basis only. She has been with MCDT for four years, servicing her fifth loan, working all this time with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second-hand clothes. She is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and starting importing clothes herself. .

loans.use: To buy more bales of second-hand clothing

loans.name: Laurence

texts.en:
Laurence manages a 1.5-hectare rice field in Surallah, South Cotabato. He also has a business in piggery. He strives and works hard to provide the basic needs of the family.

He would like to have additional capital for his business. He joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. because it has low interest financing. He’s now requesting a loan of Php 8,000 to buy supplies needed for his farm and piglets.

loans.use: farm supplies and piglets

loans.name: Hadjah

texts.en:
Hadjah is 48 years of age, married, with five children. All her children go to school. The family resides in and owns a two-roomed house where she stays with six people. She takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water at home. The family gets three meals a day.

Hadjah's greatest monthly expenses include paying utility bills, medication, and feeding the family. Hadjah owns a stall selling second-hand clothes and she serves an average of 20 customers a day. She has done this business for over ten years. She incurs transport costs to and from buying clothes from Owino. Her main challenges are seasonality and transportation of second-hand clothing from Owino Market to her place of work in Bwaise market. She sells retail and wholesale. She has been with MCDT for ten years, servicing her twentieth loan.

Hadjah wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second-hand clothes. She is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and starting importing clothes herself. .

loans.use: To buy more bales of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en:
Harriet is 51 years of age, married, with five children. All her children go to school. The family resides in and owns a two-roomed house where she stays with six people. She takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water at home. The family gets three meals a day.

Harriet's greatest monthly expenses include paying utility bills, medication, and feeding the family. Harriet owns a shop where she does tailoring and she serves an average of 20 customers a day. She has done this business for over twenty years. She incurs transport costs to and from buying clothing materials from Kampala city shops. Her main challenges are seasonality and transportation of clothing materials to her shop in Bwaise. She sells retail and wholesale.

Harriet has been with MCDT for ten years, servicing her twentieth loan. Harriet wants to use this loan to buy more rolls of cloth. She is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and starting a tailoring school. .

loans.use: to buy more bolts of cloth

loans.name: Laurence

texts.en:
Laurence manages a 1.5-hectare rice field in Surallah, South Cotabato.  He also has business in piggery. He strives hard for work to provide the basic needs of his family.

He would like to have an additional capital for his business.  He joins Community Economic Ventures, Inc. because it has a low interest in financing.  He’s now requesting a loan of Php 8,000 to buy supplies needed at his farm and piglets.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Tsiagu

texts.en: Tsiagu G. has requested 200,000 francs (XFA) in order to purchase cocoa, yams, sweet and Irish potatoes, corn, beans, groundnuts and chicken. The products will eventually be sold in Nkwen market. She is married to Asegah Christopher and the mother of three children. Tsiagu G. is currently requesting her second loan from GHAPE. She has been with GHAPE since 2007 and has demonstrated a creditworthy character exemplified by her repayments, consistent attendance of meetings, and support of her borrowing group. With this latest loan, Tsiagu G. is hoping to continue the business practices supported by her prior loans. She is confident that her business will succeed because her stall is in a strategic position within the market. She also feels that her friendly approach to customers makes a big difference. Tsiagu G. hopes to use the profits from her business to provide for the various needs of her family. She hopes to increase her profits in order to have enough to pay for her children’s school fees, open an account and provide her family’s nourishment. Tsiagu G.’s loan will be provided through Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment(GHAPE), a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase corn, groundnuts, beans and fowls

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Rice farming is the main source of earning a living of Flora, 46 years old. She owns a rice field in Surallah, South Cotabato. The eldest of her five children is 20 years old. She strives hard in order to support the education of her children.

She needs financial support for her business. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and is requesting a loan amounting to Php 15,000. With this amount she can purchase farm inputs. This way the basic needs of her family will be met.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita A. currently lives in Nkwen, Cameroon, and is the widowed mother of three children. She has been with GHAPE since 2007 and has demonstrated a creditworthy character exemplified by her repayments, her consistent attendance at meetings and her support of her borrowing group. She is currently requesting her third loan from GHAPE. 

With this latest loan Rita is hoping to continue the business supported by her prior loans. She has requested 400,000 XFA in order to purchase lumber and to pay for the labor of converting it into firewood to sell.

Rita is confident that her business will continue to do well because of her experience in this industry. She understands her customers, their demands and the increasing need for firewood in her area. She is confident that her business will continue to provide revenue for reinvestment and to meet her family’s needs.

Rita hopes to use the profits from her business to provide for her children including providing her family with meals. She will also be utilizing the revenue to take care of some personal medical needs.

Rita’s loan will be provided through the Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE), a non-profit NGO (non-governmental organization) based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients

loans.use: To buy more timber and to pay for its conversion into firewood to sell

loans.name: Alimova Halchahon`s Group

texts.en:
Halchahon, 48, is the leader of this group. She is married and has 4 sons: the two elder ones help out with the family business and other two are students. Her husband works in their own mill which is located at their house. The other family income source is livestock breeding. At the present time they have 3 milk cows, 3 bulls, 1 calf, and 25 sheep. Our client mainly has been occupied with this business for the last 17 years. Notable that it all began with just 1 cow! The requested loan will be used to buy 1 milk cow, and she is going to sell the milk to the local population. Her annual income from livestock per month is approximately US$ 100. She has set a goal for herself in the near future: marry her sons and build houses for them.

Matlyuba, 36, is the mother of 3 children. All her children are high school students. She is a farmer. She will use the loan to buy a bull to breed and sell later. Her husband at the present time is in Russia. He is working there as a cook. She says that they are working to save enough money to send their children to study in university.

Dilbar, 70, is a widow. She has two sons: both of them are working abroad. Despite her age, she is busy with livestock breeding. Currently she has 15 sheep, 2 cows and few calves. She needs a loan to buy 4 lambs. Shamshihon is 48 years old. She is married with 7 children. The two elder ones are married. The other children are students. Her husband is working in Russia in a factory. Shamshihon will use this loan to buy one cow to breed. The annual income from this business is US$ 120. She always tries to reinvest income in her business as much as possible.

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to buy livestock to raise

loans.name: Luz Marina

texts.es:
Luz Marina S. Gutiérrez tiene 55 años y vive en el barrio Ciudadela 20 de Julio de la Ciudad de Barranquilla. Se dedica a la mercancía en general y tiene tres hijos de 30, 28 y 19 años. Es un cliente desde hace 20 años en la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo y ha recibido 29 créditos durante este tiempo que han cambiado mucho su nivel de vida, incluso varios con fines educativos para sus hijos. Y éste que ahora solicita es para cancelar el 5º semestre de su hija menor.
Su niñez transcurrió al lado de sus padres y sus doce hermanos en el barrio Nueva Esperanza; desde los 12 años trabajando en la venta de vestidos de niños y otras mercancías, pagaba las mensualidades de su escuela y ayudaba al sustento de su familia, con las utilidades que de ello obtenía; golpeada por calamidades domésticas  tuvo que abandonar los estudios de bachiller a mitad del camino e iniciar su trabajo en un almacén como empleada,  donde gradualmente ganó la confianza de sus jefes y sin ninguna preparación llegó a ser la administradora de este negocio, del cual se  retiró 10 años después. Con el producto de su liquidación compró la vivienda en la que aun habita al lado de sus tres hijos, que son su razón de ser y quienes la impulsan a trabajar y esforzarse diariamente para sacarlos adelante.
Luz Marina, con el lema, “nunca miro hacia atrás, siempre adelante”, es una mujer luchadora que en condición de separada desde hace 17 años, tiene como carta de presentación un trabajo independiente, honesto y responsable con el cual ha logrado darle a sus tres hijos estudios profesionales; ella ha sido apoyada con créditos educativos para su familia, que sólo reciben los buenos clientes de la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, entidad que también le ha otorgado financiamiento para fortalecer su negocio de venta de mercancías al detalle, las cuales distribuye en toda Barranquilla. 
Manifiesta que su negocio de venta de calzado, ropa, electrodomésticos, prendas de oro y plata, variedades y papelería tiene 30 años de estar funcionando y su buen funcionamiento es producto de la experiencia adquirida en un almacén como empleada y del ingreso al programa de créditos de la Fundación, que le ha prestado dinero para aumentar su capital de trabajo, lo cual le ha representado prosperidad y le ha permitido cumplir muchos de sus proyectos y metas, uno de los cuales es ver a su última hija realizada como profesional para lo cual aplica a un crédito por valor de $1.575.532y el otro es tener un local propio en el centro de la ciudad  pues toda su vida se ha dedicado al comercio de mercancías variadas y quiere seguir creciendo.
Con la experiencia de sus años de negociante dice que “Todo no es ganancia”. Sus clientes compran sus mercancías a crédito y en ciertos momentos ha habido clientes con los que le ha tocado perder, y por eso toma en cuenta las referencias y quiere que sus clientes sean empleados. Sueña con que su hija termine la universidad y es su meta de tener un local en el centro de Barranquilla.
texts.en:
Luz Marina S. G. is 55 years old. She lives in the Ciudadela 20 de Julio neighborhood in the city of Baranquilla. She works in general merchandise and she has three children: 30, 28 and 19 years old. She has been a client of the Fundacion Mario Santo Domingo for 20 years and she has received 29 credits during that time. They have really changed her lifestyle, including the education goals of her children. This one that she is asking for now is to pay for her younger daughter's 5th semester. She grew up with her parents and her twelve siblings in the Nueva Esperanza neighborhood. Since she was twelve, she has been working selling childrens' dresses and other merchandise. She would pay her monthly tuition and help support her family with the profits she obtained. Suffering from domestic trauma, she had to leave her high school studies halfway through and begin to work as a store employee. Gradually, she gained the confidence of her bosses and without any schooling in it became the manager of this business. She left this ten years later. With her severance package she bought the home she still lives in with her three children. They are her reason for being and it is they who drive her to work and make an effort every day to get them ahead. Luz Marina, with the motto "I never look back, only ahead", is a fighter who has been separated for the last 17 years. Her business card is an independent, honest and responsible job with which she has been able to give her three children professional educations. She has been supported with education loans for her family. These are only given to good clients at the Fundacion Mario Santo Domingo. This organization has given her financing to strengthen her business of merchandise sales, which she distributes throughout Baranquilla. She states that her business is the sale of shoes, clothing, appliances, gold and silver jewelry, miscelaneous and paper products. It has been going for 30 years and its smooth operation is the product of her experience acquired as a store employee and from entering the loan program at the Fundacion, which has lent her money to increase her working capital. This has meant prosperity for her and has allowed her to finish many of her projects and goals. One of these is to watch her youngest daughter become a professional. This is why she is aplying for a loan in the amount of $1.575.532. Another goal is to have her own locale in the center of town. All of her life she has been in the business of various merchandise and she wants to continue growing. With her years of experience as a business person, she says that "It's not all profit." Her clients buy her merchandise on credit and at times she has had to lose with some clients. This is why she takes references into account and she wants her clients to be employed. Her dream is for her daughter to finish college and her goal is to have a locale in downtown Baranquilla.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Her daughter's college education

loans.name: Lina Esther

texts.es:
Lina B. A., mujer de 51 años vive en el barrio Alcibia, lugar conocido como uno de los  semilleros   musicales de la ciudad de Cartagena de Indias, donde ella dice que habitan personas amables, tranquilas y respetuosas; Lina es una mujer comerciante que ama hacer negocio, vende un alimento, elaborado a partir de la leche de vaca inducida a cuajarse, este es el famoso queso costeño  que no puede faltar en la mesa de las familias cartageneras. Así mismo elabora productos derivados de la harina de trigo rellenos de queso como son las deliciosas  empanadas y deditos y simultáneamente vende mercancía, especialmente calzado para damas, aprovechando cada época y su extensa clientela, pues responde oportunamente a lo que el mercado necesita. 

Lina B.  está casada tiene 2 hijos en edades de 18 y 20 años, a los que en unión de su esposo ha apoyado en el estudio de la ingeniería electrónica y de sistema; todos en casa se encuentran muy gratificados con la diversidad de actividades que desempeña su esposa y madre; ellos reconocen su talento y la admiran por su gran capacidad de trabajo.

En la actualidad aspira a un crédito por valor de $1.000.000; el cual tendrá una inversión dividida entre la compra de queso, suero, insumos para elaborar congelados y calzado de damas, negocio en el que ha incursionado hace alrededor de un año.

Lina inició su negocio hace 6 años y posteriormente fue impulsada por la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, con financiamiento en la línea de capital de trabajo. Desde entonces su negocio ha crecido y ella también, de la mano de las múltiples  actividades que realiza  simultáneamente, conjugando muy bien las tareas de hogar, las personales y las del negocio.
texts.en:
Lina B. A. is a 51 year old woman who lives in the Alcibia neighborhood, known as the one of the birthplaces of the music of the city of Cartagena de Indias. They say the people of Cartagena are friendly, peaceful and tolerant. Lina is an entrepreneur who loves business, selling foods made from milk curds. This is the famous costeño cheese (from the coast) that is always present in the meals of Cartagena families. She also makes foods from flour filled with cheese such as the delicious empanadas and “deditos”(a rolled cheese pastry). Besides these products, she sells merchandise such as women’s shoes, taking advantage of each season for her large customer base. She brings in what the market calls for. Lina B. is married, and has two children of 18 and 20. Along with her husband she has supported them in their studies of electrical and systems engineering. The family is very happy with the diversity of activities of their wife and mother. They appreciate her talent and admire how much she is able to do. Now she hopes for a loan of $1.000.000 ($525) which she will use to buy cheese, whey, ingredients to make ice creams, and women’s shoes. She started this part of her business about a year ago. Lina began her business 6 years ago and was later was helped by the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo with the financing for working capital. Since then her business has grown and she as well, from the work of her many activities that she can do simultaneously, combining the chores at home, personal needs, and those of her business.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cheese, whey, ingredients to make ice cream and to sell shoes

loans.name: Alexi

texts.es:
En un taller de confecciones en el barrio Campestre de la ciudad de Cartagena, hay una mujer dotada de creatividad, que enseña un arte del que  ha vivido siempre, a jóvenes para que encuentren en él una forma de ganarse la vida honradamente, como lo ha hecho ella ella desde que abrió su taller de Confecciones en su propia casa, con el que devenga un salario para apoyar la gestión de su familia junto a su esposo, que trabaja como vigilante. Esta mujer es Alexi L., tiene 42 años de edad y tres hijos de 22, 16 y 14 años, actualmente estudiando simultáneamente en carreras técnica, profesional y de bachiller; con ellos está asociada su meta principal: “Educarlos y apoyar su formación profesional, para que teniendo acceso a oportunidades  sean unas personas de bien”.     

Para Alexi, la Hermosa ciudad de Cartagena de Indias, la heroica, con su mezcla de arquitectura moderna y Colonial, ha sido el escenario perfecto donde se inició con una vieja maquina de coser y un mercado domestico entre vecinos, familiares y amigos cercanos, que le llevaban las telas para que elaborar sus vestidos; al principio debió pagar el servicio de fileteado, pues no tenia maquinaria para realizar esta operación, que le daba el acabado perfecto a sus productos. Por eso cuando escuchó hablar de la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo a sus vecinos, no dudó en solicitar el apoyo de su primer financiamiento para compra la fileteadora que tanto necesitaba  y telas e insumos con los cuales empezó a elaborar sus primeras creaciones, para venderlas con gran aceptación de la clientela; esto hizo que pensara en capacitarse e inició seminarios de diseño de modas para el perfeccionamiento de su técnica y al observar como su negocio crecía gradualmente, se arriesgó a  reemplazar su vieja y apreciada maquina de coser. 

Aunque ella desea profesionalizarse en diseño de modas, dice que su primer compromiso es ver a sus hijos convertidos en profesionales y ella debe esperar su momento, por eso está apuntándole con esfuerzos entusiastas a su negocio y se mantiene actualizada con cursos cortos que le permiten estar atenta a las nuevas tendencias de la moda y los requerimientos de su mercado.

Alexi ha recibido varios créditos de la Fundación, siete de los cuales en la línea de capital de trabajo y los dos últimos de educación, que consideran son de mucha importancia para que ella no tenga que recurrir a agiotistas y endeude su patrimonio, como lo hacia antes de estar con la Fundación. El crédito al que aplica y con el que espera ser apoyada en pro del bienestar de su familia, esta dirigido a pagarle el último semestre universitario en la carrera de contaduría Publica a James, su hijo mayor, quien sin graduarse trabaja como auxiliar contable y se prepara para ayudar a que sus hermanos alcancen sus sueños educativos.

Desde su vinculación al programa de la Fundación, Alexi ha visto su negocio crecer, pudo renovar su maquinaria de confección y ha sacado a sus hijos adelante especialmente en lo relacionado con la educación. Su principal desafío familiar siempre ha sido el cumplimiento con la multiplicidad de sus rolles como esposa, madre y empresaria; Ella considera que la educación de los hijos es tarea de los padres y no las delega como ocurre cuando ambos padres trabajan.

Alexi y su esposo han levantado a sus hijos en el barrio Campestre, ubicado en el suroccidente de la hermosa Cartagena, este un lugar modesto con calles angostas, vecinos solidarios, muchos escenarios deportivos y una pista de patinaje público, donde la comunidad ha visto de cerca los juegos Centroamericanos y del Caribe. En el escenario del barrio Campestre, es común  ver los vecinos practicando el patinaje, por eso se ha convertido en el semillero de futuras estrellas de este deporte, en el que Colombia se destaca con la muy joven  Cecilia “la Chechi Baena, que se mantiene arrasando con medallas en cada mundial  y ha sido 6 veces campeona en la máxima categoría del patinaje en línea; la Chechi como todos la llaman, es la insignia y el parámetro que impulsa a muchos jóvenes de la comunidad a progresar, este es el ambiente donde también Alexi y su esposo ha educado a sus tres hijos.
texts.en:
In a seamstress shop in the Campestre neighborhood of the city of Cartagena, there is a woman who is gifted with creativity. She teaches the art, which she has always had, to youngsters. She does this so that they can, through their creativity, find an honorable way of earning a living like she has done. She opened her seamstress shop in her own house, and she earns a salary to help her husband support the family. Her husband is a watchman. This woman is Alexi Lópex. She is 42, and she has three children; 22, 16, and 14. The children are currently simultaneously studying a technical career, a professional career, and a high school degree. Her primary goal for them is, “To educate them and support their professional training so that they have access to opportunities and become good people”. For Alexi, the beautiful city of Cartagena de Indias, the heroic, with its mixture of modern and colonial architecture, has been the perfect place to start with an old sewing machine and a domestic market among her neighbors, family, and close friends. They brought her fabrics in order for her to make their clothes. At first she had to pay for the finishing service because she did not have a machine to do this operation and give a perfect finishing to her products. That is why when she heard her neighbors talking about the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation; she did not hesitate in asking for the support of her first loan to buy an overlock sewing machine, which she needed so much. She also needed fabrics and supplies to make her first creations. They were widely accepted by the customers who bought them. This made her think of training, and she started fashion design seminars to perfect her technique. She saw how her business gradually grew, and she took a chance on replacing her prized old sewing machine. Even though she wishes to become a professional in fashion design, she says that her first commitment is to see her children become professionals. She needs to wait for her time. That is why she is enthusiastically putting her efforts into her business. She stays fulfilled with short courses that allow her to be aware of the new fashion trends and the market’s requirements. Alexi has received various loans from the Foundation. Seven of them have been for working capital. The last two have been for education. She considers them to be very important so that she does not have to go to moneylenders and put up her assets for the debt. This is what she did before she was with the Foundation. The loan she is asking for and hopes to receive for her family’s well being is to pay for the last the last semester of study in the university for her oldest son, James. He is studying for a career in Public Accounting. Without graduating he works as an accounting assistant. He is preparing to help his sibling reach their educational dreams. Alexi has seen her business grow since joining the program with the Foundation. She was able to renovate her sewing machinery, and she has been able to get her children ahead, especially in the area of education. Her main family challenge has always been fulfilling her multiple rolls as wife, mother, and business person. She considers the education of the children to be the parents’ job, and she does not delegate that as it happens when both parents work. Alexi and her husband have raised their children in the Campestre neighborhood, which is southwest of the beautiful Cartagena. It is a modest place with narrow streets, united neighbors, many sporting areas, and a public skating rink where the community has seen the Central American games of the Caribbean up close. In the Campestre neighborhood it is common to see the neighbors practicing their skating, and it has become the source of future stars of this sport. Colombia stands out in this sport with the very young Cecilia, “La Chechi Baena”, who keeps winning medals in each world competition. She has been a champion six times in the category of in line skating. “La Chechi”, as everyone calls her, is the symbol and parameter that motivates lots of youngsters of the community to progress. This is the atmosphere in which Alexi and her husband have educated their three children.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For her son's education

loans.name: Azimjon

texts.ru: Эмомов Азимджон проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст, 61 год. Женат, имеет 9 детей. Эмомов Азимджон животноводством занимается более 10 лет. Он откармливает и продает крупно- рогатый скот. Эмомов Азимджон хочет увеличить их количество и получить большую приболь. Кредит берет для закупа крупно- рогатого скота.
texts.en:
E. Azimjon lives in the Hamadoni region. He's sixty-one years old, married and has nine children. For more than ten years he has bred livestock: fattening and then selling large cattle. E. wants to increase the head count of his herd and earn a profit, so he is requesting a loan to buy more cattle.

Translated from Russian by Alex Kostrubsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cattle

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Shifo

texts.ru: Салимова Шифо проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст, 26 лет. Замужем, имеет 5 детей. Салимова Шифо торговлей занимается более 7 лет. Она покупает и продает мужскую одежду. Кредит берет для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Shifo S. lives in the Hamadoni district. She is 26 years old, married and has 5 children. Shifo has been involved in retail sales for over 7 years. She buys and sells men's clothing. She is requesting this loan in order to increase goods turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing goods turnover

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Samadhodja

texts.ru: Баходурходжаев Самадходжа проживает  в городе Куляб. Возраст, 52 года. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Баходурходжаев Самадходжа таксистом работает более 4 лет. Он занимается перевозками. Кредит берет для ремонта автомашины, чтобы предоставить безопасную услугу.
texts.en:
Samadhodja B. lives in the city of Kulob. He is 62 years old, married and has 4 children. Samadhodja has been working as a taxi driver for over 4 years. He is involved in transport. He is requesting this loan for car repairs in order to provide safe service.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Car repairs

loans.name: Maria Margarita

texts.es:
María Margarita L. García tiene 53 años y vive en el barrio Claret de Bogotá, la ciudad  más poblada de Colombia  y su Centro Cultural y Económico más importante. En esta ciudad, llamada también "La Atenas Sudamericana”, residen personas provenientes de todo el país, que han venido contribuyendo con las antiguas  tradiciones culturales de Bogotá, introduciendo a sus nuevas generaciones  formas de ser y hacer las cosas;  este es el caso de María Margarita que proveniente de Cúcuta, su ciudad natal, perteneciente al Departamento de  Norte de Santander, llegó a Bogotá hace siete años, para estar cerca de sus hijos que venían buscando la oportunidad de educarse y formarse como oficiales de policía en la Capital de Colombia. María Margarita desde su ciudad de origen practicaba la actividad  comercial, la cual trasladó al barrio  Claret de Bogotá, ubicado cerca de la Escuela Militar y caracterizado por ser un sector comercial, donde se encuentran bancos, almacenes de ropa, librerías y que debe su nombre a la comunidad claretiana desde que fuè bendecido por sacerdotes pertenecientes a la misma.  Esta fuè la Infraestructura poblacional encontrada y aprovechada por ella cuando  incursionó  en la venta de productos por catálogo en este barrio. Aunque dice, que no es fácil vivir en otra ciudad lejos de la familia donde no te conocen y que la dedicación en la educación de sus hijos, los costos de las carreras militares y el cambio de ciudad requieren de mucho dinero, lo cual parece ser su principal desafió.

En la actualidad está casada y tiene dos hijos de 27 y 25 años, que ya son policías; su negocio consiste en la venta por catálogo de joyería, jeans y bolsos; éste es su primer crédito con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, organización con la que ha participado en procesos formativos para adquirir y aumentar destrezas en el manejo del mercado y del crédito empresarial; María Margarita aplica a un crédito por valor de $1.500.000 para comprar dos mostrarios de  joyería que contienen aproximadamente dos docenas y media de aretes, seis anillos y seis cadenas. Su sueño relacionado con el negocio es afiliarse a la Cooperativa de la Policía Nacional y posicionar un stand. La meta de la familia es crear una empresa conjunta de electrotécnica, para la cual los hijos están estudiando al mismo tiempo que trabajan; con ese panorama, ella estaría disponiendo de su experiencia mercadológica y la capacidad emprendedora que la caracteriza.
texts.en:
María Margarita L. García, 53, lives in the Claret neighborhood in Bogotá. It is the most heavily populated area of Colombia, and it is its most important cultural and economic center. It is also called “The Athens of South America”. People from all over the country live here, and they have contributed the ancient cultural traditions of Bogotá. They are introducing new generations to ways of being and doing things. This is the case with María Margarita. She is from Cúcuta of the Norte de Santandar department, and she came to Bogotá seven years ago to be close to her children. Her children came looking for the opportunity to educate themselves and become police officials in the capital of Colombia. María Margarita had a commercial activity in her native city, and she moved it to the Claret neighborhood in Bogotá. It is located near the Military School. This is a commercial area where you can find banks, clothing shops, and book stores. The name comes from the Claretiana Community, which was blessed by priests who lived there. This was how the infrastructure was when she decided to sell her products by catalog in this neighborhood. They say that it is not easy to live in another city far from your family where people do not know you. Also, you need a lot of money to devote to the education of your children, the costs of military careers, and to change cities. This appears to be her biggest challenge. She is currently married, and she has two children; 27 and 25. They are now police officers. Her business consists of catalog sales of jewelry, jeans, and purses. This is her first loan with the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation. She has participated with the organization in learning processes to increase her skills in managing the market and entrepreneurial loans. María Margarita is applying for a loan for 1,500,000 COP to buy two jewelry display packages that have approximately two and a half dozen earrings, six rings, and six chains. Her business dream is to affiliate herself with the National Police Cooperative and set up a stand. Her family goal is to create a business jointly with technical electronics. Her children are studying this at the same time as they are working. With this outlook, she will be using her marketing experience and her characteristic entrepreneurial capacity.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy two jewelry display packages that have approximately two and a half dozen earrings, six rings, and six chains

loans.name: Loida

texts.en:
Loida, 64, is a rice farmer who manages two and a half rice fields. She also does dressmaking as an additional income source for her family. She has 4 children to support. She wants to sustain her businesses by the help of a micro-finance institution. She heard about Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and joined in November 2007.

She's now requesting a loan of 15,000 Php, enough to provide the farming materials. This is very helpful since the loan only has a low interest rate.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Lovelyn

texts.en:
Rice farming is the main source of income for 22-year-old Lovelyn. She also has a piggery and a cell phone reload business. She lacks capital to finance her businesses – that's why she joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She has requested 8,000 Philippine pesos to buy farm supplies and feed for the pigs.

Lovelyn is the mother of two children (the eldest is 4 years old). She wants them to have a bright future and to provide for their needs. This loan will be of great help.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and feed

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
Luz, 38, a member of Community Economic Ventures, Inc., has requested a loan of 15,000 Php as additional capital for her business in rice farming. She tills a 1-hectare rice field in Surallah, South Cotabato. She maintains the farm very well to have a plentiful harvest.

In 1999 she started rice farming. She now has 2 children; her eldest is 11 years old. With rice farming, she has been able to provide for the basic needs of her family. This loan will help a lot to purchase farm supplies.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Maria Fe

texts.en: Maria Fe is 22 years old and has a vegetable and fruit farming business. She has an eight-year-old child. She does everything to lift up her family. This is the only way she can provide for their needs. She's now requesting a loan of 10,000 Philippine pesos to buy farm seeds and supplies. This loan is helpful for her to continue with her business.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Elisabeth

texts.fr:
Madmoiselle Elisabeth Mbendy est une femme celibataire de 32 ans qui habite dans la banlieue de Guediawaye,plus particulierement dans le quartier de Nimzath Kawsara. Elle est societaire de la caisse depuis juillet 2000 et a deja beneficie de 3 prets anterieurs.C'est le commerce qu'elle a choisi comme activite. Et elle est tres connue dans la vente de tissus,parfums,creme de corps,draps et divers autres articles. Elle capitalise une experience de 8 ans dans cette activite.C'est le fait qu'elle n'a pes pu reussir dans ses etudes qui l'a pousse a choisir cette activite pour etre a l'abri du chomage. Auparavant elle a demarre par des voyages sur la petite cote pour acheter des poissons fumes qu'elle revendait a Dakar. Les moments les plus favorables de son activite sont les periodes de fete de Tabaski,de Korite,et de fin d'annees.
Mademoiselle M. sollicite un credit de 250 000 frs pour renforcer son stock de tissuet de parfum et en meme temps elle souhaiterait relancer sa buvette qui etait en instance. Son plus grand reve est de voyager dans la sous region et meme a Doubai. Les differents credits qu'elle a consenti l'ont beaucoup aide a epargner,a satisfaire ses besoins personnels,a supporter certaines charges de ses soeurset a pratiquer l'elevage de moutons.
texts.en:
Mademoiselle Elisabeth M., aged 32 and single, lives on the outskirts of Guediawaye, more precisely, in the Nimzath Kawsara neighborhood. She has been a member of U-IMCEC since July 2000 and has already received three loans. She chose commercial activities as her business sector. She is well known for her sales of cloth, perfume, body cremes, sheets, and various other items. She can boast of eight years' experience in this field.

The fact that she did not do well in school pushed her to choose commercial activities so as not to be jobless. Earlier, she began by making trips to the bay to buy smoked fish that she then sold in Dakar. The best times for her business are the feast days of 'Tabaski', 'Korite', and the New Year's festivities.

Mademoiselle M. is requesting a loan of 250,000 frs to bolster her inventory of cloth and perfume, and she would also like to re-open her snack bar which was on hiatus. Her great dream is to travel farther afield and even to Dubai. The various loans she has received have helped her a lot in being able to put aside savings, support herself, pay certain expenses for her sisters, and raise sheep.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: add to her working capital

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.es:
Mercedes es socia del Banco Comunal Hormigas.

Mercedes es casada, tiene 49 años y 6 hijos, Mercedes venD. comida D. manera ambulatoria en el mercado D. abastos D. L. ciudad D. Ayacucho, actividad que realiza todos los días por las mañanas. Además Mercedes venD. golosinas en L. puerta D. su casa.

Mercedes necesita un préstamo D. 2000 soles dinero que será invertido en L. compra D. golosinas.

Los sueños D. Mercedes son que sus hijos salgan adelante, tener un restaurante en su casa.
texts.en:
Mercedes is a member of the Hormigas (“Ants”) Communal Bank. Mercedes is 49 years old, married, and has 6 children. Every morning Mercedes sells food as a traveling street vendor in the city of Ayacucho’s wholesale food market. In addition, Mercedes sells candies from the entrance to her home. Mercedes needs a loan of 2000 soles, and will use the money to invest in the purchase of candies. Mercedes’ dream is that her children can get ahead, and to have a restaurant in her home.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing candies

loans.name: Elsa Lucia

texts.es: Elsa tiene 23 años de edad ella es soltera vive  en la casa de sus padres juntamente con sus hermanos ellos viven  en el Asentamiento Humano Micaela Bastidas  en casa de 1 piso de material  noble, ella se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza y la venta de bebidas en la casa de sus padres, Elsa es una joven muy activa con muchas metas y objetivos uno de ellos es poder crecer en su negocio, con el dinero que solicita  invertira en capital de trabajo de la venta de productos de belleza.
texts.en:
Elsa is 23 years old, single, and lives in her parent’s house along with her brothers. They live in Asentamiento Humano Micaela Bastidas in a one floor house made of good materials. She sells beauty products, and drinks, from her parent’s house. She is very young and active and has lots of goals and plans. One of which is to be able to grow her business with a loan she would invest as working capital in the sale of beauty products.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To implement her business

loans.name: Ruth Constanza

texts.es:
Ruth es socia del Banco Comunal Hormigas.
Ruth es casada, tiene 49 años y 3 hijos, Ruth vende ropa a pedido, sus ventas los realiza a amigos y familiares al crédito, actividad que realiza todos los días.
Ruth necesita un préstamo de 2000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de sacos, pantalones.
Los sueños de Ruth son aumentar su mercadería y educar a su ultimo hijo.
texts.en:
Ruth is a member of the Hormigas (“Ants”) Communal Bank. Ruth is 49 years old, married, and has 3 children. Ruth sells clothing by special order. She works every day selling her products to friends and relatives. Ruth needs a loan of 2000 soles, and will use the money to invest in the purchase of jackets and pants. Ruth’s dream is to increase her merchandise and to educate her youngest child.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing jackets and pants

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
Maria es socia del Banco Comunal Hormigas.
Maria es casada, tiene 35 años y 3 hijos, Maria vende frutas de manera ambulatoria en el mercado Señor de Arequipa, actividad que realiza todos los días. Además compra cacao en la selva ayacuchana y lo vende a intermediarios.
Maria necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de frutas.
Maria sueña con que sus hijos estudien y progresen, aumentar su negocio.
texts.en:
Maria is a member of the Hormigas (“Ants”) Communal Bank Maria is 35 years old, married, and has 3 children. Maria works every day selling fruits as a traveling street vendor in the Señor de Arequipa market. In addition, she also purchases cacao in the Ayacuchan jungle and sells it to middlemen. Maria needs a loan of 1000 soles, and will use the money to invest in the purchase of fruits. Maria’s dream is for her children to study and make progress, and to increase her business.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing fruits

loans.name: Maymouna

texts.fr:
Madame Maymouna T. habite a Yoff plus précisément dans le quartier de Mbenguenne.Elle est âgée de 64 ans et est membre de la caisse de Yoff depuis mars 2001. Elle a déjà bénéficié de 3 prêts antérieurs. Elle est mariée sans enfant mais s’active dans la vente de pomme de terre frite, de jus, de crème et aussi dans la couture. Elle capitalise une expérience d’un peu plus de deux ans. Les coupures intempestives d’électricité sont la principale raison d’arrêt de son activité de couture. Ainsi elle oriente tous ses efforts dans la vente de jus et de frites. Par conséquent elle sollicite un crédit de 200 000 frs pour constituer un stock des éléments qu’elle utilise pour réaliser ses produits (pomme de terre, lait en poudre, sucre). Son objectif est de maximiser ses profits afin qu’elle puisse satisfaire ses besoins personnels et aussi initier des projets futurs ;tout ceci dans le but d’améliorer le cadre de vie familial.

Madame Maymouna a été pris en photo dans sa chambre ici.
texts.en:
Mrs Maimouna T. lives in Yoff, more specifically in the Mbenguenne neighborhood. She is 64 years old and has been a member of the Yoff credit union since March 2001. She already benefited from three previous loans. She is married without children but keeps busy selling French fries, fruit juice and custard. She also has a sewing activity. She counts a little over two years of experience. Untimely power cuts are the main reason for her discontinuing her sewing activity and redirecting all her efforts towards selling juice and fries. Therefore she is requesting a 200,000 francs loan to build up a stock of the ingredients she uses to make her products (potatoes, powdered milk, sugar). Her objective is to maximize profits to fulfill her personal needs and also to initiate future projects; this is all in order to improve her family's living conditions. Madame Malmouna is pictured here in her home.

Translated from French by Charlotte Buecheler, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: increase in working capital

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es:
Margarita es socia del Banco Comunal Hormigas.

Margarita es soltera, tiene 58 años y 1 hijo, Margarita tiene una pollería en su casa, actividad que realiza por las noches con la ayuda de 2 personas. Además tiene una farmacia en la ciudad de Lima negocio que es administrado por su hijo.

Margarita necesita un préstamo de 2,000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de medicinas.

Margarita sueña con ser empresaria y que su hijo sea profesional.
texts.en:
Margarita is a member of the Hormigas (“Ants”) Communal Bank. Margarita is 58 years old, single, and has 1 son. Margarita has a ‘polleria’ (chicken restaurant) in her home, which she runs at night with the help of 2 employees. In addition, she has a pharmacy in the city of Lima, a business that her son operates for her. Margarita needs a loan of 2000 soles, and will use the money to invest in the purchase of medicines. Margarita’s dream is to be a businesswoman and for her son to be a professional.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing medicines

loans.name: Mamadou

texts.fr: Monsieur Mamadou D. est un marie de 36 ans père d’un enfant et habitant à Yoff dans le quartier de Ndennatte.Il est sociétaire de la caisse de yoff depuis 2001 et a déjà bénéficié de 6 crédits antérieurs au sein de l’institution. Il est spécialisé dans le commerce de cosmétiques depuis 2001.le choix de son activité a été surtout influence par un de ses frères commerçant. Monsieur D. emprunte  500 000 frs pour renforcer son stock de lait de toilette et de parfums. Son crédita va lui permettre de mieux rentabiliser son activité et de mieux supporter financièrement l’amélioration de s conditions de vie sociale de la famille.
texts.en:
Mr. Mamadou D. is 36 year-old and the married father of a child. He lives in Yoff, in the neighborhood of Ndennatte. He has been a member of the Yoff credit union since 2001 and has already benefited from six prior loans from this institution. Since 2001, he specializes in the trade of cosmetics. His choice of activity was mainly influenced by one of his brothers, himself a merchant. Mr. D. is borrowing 500,000 francs to increase his stock of cleansing milk and perfume. This loan will allow him to make his business more profitable and to better support the improvement of his family's living conditions.

Translated from French by Charlotte Buecheler, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: increase in working capital

loans.name: Omar

texts.fr: Monsieur Omar D. est un jeune commerçant de 35 ans qui est spécialisé dans l’habillement et la vente de sachets en plastique. Il évolue dans ce domaine depuis  l’année 2000.C’est par l’intermédiaire de ses parents qu’il a choisi cette activité surtout dans le but de gagner sa vie. Il sollicite un crédit de 500 000 frs pour renforcer son stock de pantalons jean, de tee-shirt et de chemise dans l’espoir d’augmenter ses gains et améliorer la situation de sa famille dont il constitue le principal soutien. Monsieur D. est sociétaire de la caisse de yoff depuis octobre 2007. Il a déjà bénéficié d’un prêt antérieur. Il est père de 2 enfants dont l’âge varie entre 1 et 3 ans.
texts.en:
Mr Omar D. is a young merchant of 35 years who specializes in the sale of clothing and plastic bags. He has been operating in this domain since 2000. He chose this activity through his parents mostly in the objective to make a living. He is requesting a 500,000 francs loan to bolster his stock of denim trousers, T-shirts and shirts. He hopes to increase his benefits and to improve the situation of his family, for whom he is the main provider. Mr D. has been a member of the Yoff credit union since October 2007. He already benefited from a prior loan. He is the father of two children aged one and three.

Translated from French by Charlotte Buecheler, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase in working capital

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.es:
DOÑA EUGENIA COMPRA CERDOS PARA DESTASE Y VENDE CARNE DE CERDO, NACATAMALES  Y SUS DERIVADOS  TODOS LOS FINES DE SEMANA.
EL CREDITO LO NECESITA PARA COMPRAR CERDOS POR MAYOR  POR QUE DE ESA MANERA DISMINUYEN LOS COSTOS POR QUE DE ESA MANERA COMPRA A MENOS PRECIOS LOS CERDOS 
ESTA SEÑORA ES MADRE SOLTERA Y TIENE 10 HIJOS LOS CUALES LOS A CRIADO CON MUCHO ESFURZO Y SIEMPRE TRABAJANDO EN ESTE NEGOCIO
texts.en:
Doña Eugenia buys pigs to butcher and sell the meat. She also makes nacatamales (traditional food of corn dough filled with meat or veggies and steamed in banana leaves) and other similar food to sell daily. She needs the loan to buy pigs in bulk so that her costs go down since the price is lower buying in this way. She is a single mother with 10 children which she raises with great strength, always working in her business.

Translated from Spanish by Sierra Visher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pigs and sell the meat and other food products made from the meat

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr: Madame Fatou N. est une yoffoise de38 ans qui habite a la cite Mame Rane, une des cites environnantes de Yoff. Elle est membre de l’U-IMCEC depuis janvier 2009et n’a bénéficié d’un prêt antérieur. Elle est mariée et mère de 2 enfants dont l’âge varie entre 5 et 14 ans. Son activité préférée demeure la couture qu’elle exerce avec beaucoup de passion. Plus précisément  elle fait la couture générale, vend des habits et des tissus qu’elle confectionne. Elle capitalise une expérience de 6 ans. Elle sollicite un crédit de 500 000 frs pour acquérir une machine cornière ceci dans le but de mieux répondre a la demande de sa clientèle. Une autre partie du financement sera orientée à l’achat de tissus a confectionner. Son souhait est d’augmenter ses gains et améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatou N. is a 38-year-old woman from Yoff, who lives in the Mame Rane development, one of several in the Yoff area. She is a member of the U-IMCEC credit union since January 2009, and has not been granted any prior loan. She is married and mother of two children, age 5 and 14. Her favourite activity remains sewing, which she practices with passion. Specifically, she does all-around sewing, selling clothes and fabrics that she assembles. She has an accumulated six years of experience. She is requesting a loan of 500,000 francs to purchase a special embroidery machine, to better respond to customers’ demands. Another portion of the loan will be devoted to buying pieces of fabric. Her hope is to increase her earnings and improve her family’s living conditions.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investment

loans.name: Hortencia

texts.es: Hortencia, es una mujer muy honrada, vive en el Distrito de Calleria, región Ucayali, tiene 55 años, es madre de tres hijos, uno es menor de edad, ella se dedica a la venta de gaseosas y chupetes, esta actividad la realiza en su casa, cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo que trabaja como tractorista. Hortencia forma parte del Banco Comunal “Mujeres Solidarias”, desde hace seis años,  el primer crédito que recibió fue de 300 soles, que fue invertido en la compra de gaseosas y chupetes, ahora ella necesita un crédito de 1500 soles, que será destinado a la adquisición de gaseosas e insumos y materiales para la elaboración de los chupetes. La meta de Hortencia es, ampliar su casa y su negocio para brindar un mejor servicio a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Hortencia is an honorable woman, who lives in the district of Calleria, region of Ucayali, is 55 years old, mother of three children, one of whom is minor in age. She sells soft drinks and lollies from her house and she has the support of her husband, who is a tractor worker. Hortencia has been a member of the commune bank “Mujeres Solidarias” (Solidarity Women) for six years. She used her first loan of 300 soles to buy soft drinks and lollies and now she is requesting a loan of 1500 soles to buy more soft drinks and ingredients to produce lollies. Her goal is to enlarge her house and her business, in order to provide a better service to her customers.

Translated from Spanish by MONICA URBAN, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will use the loan to purchase soft drinks and ingredients to produce lollies.

loans.name: Luis Enrrique

texts.es: El Sr. Luis 34 años de edad tiene 2 hijos de 13 y 3 años de edad es conviviente, viven en el Distrito de La Tinguiña  en casa alquilada de material de adobe de un piso. Cuentan con un terreno recientemente adquirido. El se dedica como maestro de construccion hace 10 años, se inicio como ayudante, actualmente cuenta con maquinaria de tablas y otros. El Sr. Luis es una persona activa con muchas cualidades buenas , tiene muchos sueños y objetivos uno de ellos es poder terner su casa ya construida para poder darles una mejor calidad de vida, con el dinero que solicita construira una habitacion de su casa.
texts.en:
Luis, 34, is in a common law marriage. He has two children, 13 and 3. They live in the La Tinguiña district in a rented, one floor adobe house. They have recently acquired a piece of land. He has been a construction foreman for ten years. He started as an assistant. He currently has wood working machinery and other tools. Luis is an active person with many good qualities. He has lots of dreams and objectives. One of them is to be able to have his house built in order to be able to provide a better quality of life. He will use the money he is requesting to build a room in his house.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Improvement to his house

loans.name: Rafael Antonio

texts.es:
Perfil del Cliente 	. El joven Rafael Antonio U. es trabajador de una estación de combustible (PETRONIC) desempeñándose como conductor y también como lavador de carro.
El joven U. va utilizar este crédito para la compra de fertilizantes ya que el tiene hortaliza (tomate)  sembrado en la finca de sus padres.
El objetivo de la fertilización es para obtener mayores rendimiento y por ende mayores ganancia de su cosecha.
Rafael es acompañado (soltero) y tiene 1 hijo y en edad escolar y vive con su hijo y su compañera de vida .Es el tercer crédito que ha tenido con Ceprodel Rafael dice que ha sido de gran ayuda los crédito anteriores ya que a comprado algunos electrodomésticos que necesita en su casa y a solventado algunas necesidades personales  de el.
texts.en:
Rafael Antonio U. works for a fuel station (PETRONIC) as a driver, and he also washes cars. Rafael will use this loan to buy fertilizers because he has a tomato crop planted on his parents’ farm. The objective of the fertilization is to get great output and more earnings from his harvest. Rafael is single. He lives with his life partner and his school-age child. This is the third loan that he has had with Ceprodel. Rafael says that the previous loans have been a big help. He has purchased household appliances that he needs in his house, and he has paid for some personal necessities.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fertilizers

loans.name: Rafael Antonio's Group

texts.es:
Rafael U. es trabajador de una estación de combustible en el municipio de Condega. Es muy trabajador y ha tomado la decisión de duplicar sus esfuerzos en el trabajo porque tiene una finca donde siembra tomates. Por esta razón es que solicita el crédito, para ser utilizado en la compra de fertilizantes para la siembra de hortalizas. 

Rafael es soltero y tiene un hijo y en edad escolar siendo este pequeño el que le impulsa a trabajar arduamente para llevar el sustento a su hogar.
texts.en:
Rafael Antonio U. works for a fuel station (PETRONIC) as a driver, and he also washes cars. Rafael will use this loan to buy fertilizers because he has a tomato crop planted on his parents’ farm. The objective of the fertilization is to get great output and more earnings from his harvest. Rafael is single. He lives with his life partner and his school-age child. This is the third loan that he has had with Ceprodel. Rafael says that the previous loans have been a big help. He has purchased household appliances that he needs in his house, and he has paid for some personal necessities.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fertilizers

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
