Lidia pertenece al banco comunal “las hijas D. Maria” D. la Asociación Arariwa y se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
48-year old Lidia is married and has four children. She gets up very early to do household chores such as preparing breakfast and cleaning the house. Her job is selling churros (a kind of fried doughnut) from a barrow in the street. She’s been running this business for ten years, and all has gone well thanks to the effort that she puts into her work. Lidia needs a loan to buy 20 kilos of flour. (Churros are maD. with flour, and the centre has a filling maD. of condensed milk.) Lidia belongs to Arariwa Association’s “Las Hijas D. Maria” Community Bank. She is grateful for this opportunity to obtain a loan and promises to make the repayments according to the schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy 20 kilos of flour

loans.name: Haydee

texts.es:
Haydee es socia del Banco Comunal Hormigas.
Haydee es soltera, tiene 25 años y 1 hijo, Haydee venD. choclo sancochado, actividad que realiza D. manera ambulatoria todos los días en un grifo D. L. ciudad, y por las tardes en las empresas D. transporte interprovincial. Haydee tiene proyectado iniciar con L. venta D. golosinas, panes en un kiosko.
Haydee necesita un préstamo D. 600 soles dinero que será invertido en L. compra D. choclo.
Los sueños D. Haydee son tener un negocio granD. y que su hijo culmine sus estudios.
texts.en:
Haydee is a member of the Hormigas (Ants) Community Bank. She is single, 25 years old, and has a son. She sells boiled corn cobs from an outdoor stand at a gas station during the mornings, and in the businesses at the bus terminal in the afternoons. Haydee plans to start selling candy and bread from a kiosk. She needs a loan of 600 soles to buy corn cobs. Her dream is to own a large business and to have her son complete his education.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy corn cobs

loans.name: Betty

texts.es:
Betty es socia del Banco Comunal Hormigas.
Betty es soltera, tiene 43 años y 1 hijo, Betty vende ropa a pedido, sus ventas los realiza a amigos y familiares al crédito, actividad que realiza todos los días. Además compra y vende ganado.
Betty necesita un préstamo de 600 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de polos.
Los sueños de Betty es tener casa propia y que su hijos salga adelante.
texts.en:
Betty is a member of the Communal Bank “Hormigas” (Ants). She is 43 years old, single, and has one child.

Betty sells clothing upon request. Her sales are made to friends and relatives on credit. She engages in this business every day. In addition, she buys and sells cattle.

Betty needs a loan of 600 soles in order to buy polo shirts. Her dreams include having a home of her own and seeing her children succeed.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase polo shirts

loans.name: Yolanda Elsa

texts.es:
Yolanda tiene 41 años, es conviviente y tiene dos hijos (Luis Antonio tiene 15 años y Hassle tiene 8 años). Yolanda se levanta muy temprano para hacer sus actividades del hogar como por ejemplo preparar desayuno para sus hijos. Yolanda se dedica a la venta de ropa de interior y medias. Yolanda cada mañana a las 9 a.m. acomoda su negocio en la calle Trinitarias y después de vender todo el día retorna a su casa las 6pm. Ya son cuatro años que se dedica al negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo. Yolanda requiere el préstamo para comprar más ropa interior y medias. 

Yolanda pertenece al banco comunal “las hijas de Maria” de la Asociación Arariwa y se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Yolanda is 41 years old, lives with her partner, and has two children (Luis Antonio is 15 and Hassle is 8). Yolanda gets up very early to take care of things she needs to do in the house like making breakfast for her children. Yolanda sells underwear and stockings for a living. Each morning at 9:00, Yolanda sets up her business on Trinitarias street. After selling all day, she returns home at 6:00. She has been doing this for four years and it has been going very well thanks to the effort she puts in. Yolanda needs a loan to buy more underwear and stockings. Yolanda belongs to the communal bank “Las hijas de Maria” which is part of the Arariwa Association. She is grateful for the opportunity offered her in this way and promises to make her payments on time.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Yolanda needs a loan to buy underwear and stockings

loans.name: Color Esperanza Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Color Esperanza, inicia su segundo ciclo con 15 socias. 

Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la venta de abarrotes en general, Cereales, chicha, quesos, ropa, animales menores, panes, también brindan servicio de transporte.

Como es el caso de la señora Sandra que es conviviente, tiene 23 años y 2 hijos, Sandra tiene una tienda en su casa en donde vende abarrotes en general, carnes, verduras, artículos de librería, actividad que realiza todos los días. Con el préstamo que obtendrá Sandra comprara arroz, azúcar y útiles escolares.

Mientras que Alejandra es conviviente, tiene 35 años y 6 hijos, Alejandra vende cancha de maíz, fideo, arroz de manera ambulatoria al frente de un mini hospital, actividad que realiza todos los días, Con el préstamo que obtendrá Alejandra comprara canchas surtidas.

Las socias necesitan diferentes montos de prestamos como 300 soles, 600soles, 750 soles, 1000 soles  haciendo un total de 10,750 soles de prestamos en el Banco Comunal. 

Sus prestamos serán invertidos en la compra de arroz, azúcar, útiles escolares, canchas, cereales, quesos, ropa y animales.

Los sueños de las socias son Ampliar sus negocios, sus hijos culminen sus estudios, tener casa propia.
texts.en:
The communal bank Color Esperanza started its second loan cycle with 15 members. The members are in different businesses, such as the sale of foodstuffs, cereals, chicha (a Peruvian drink), cheese, clothing, small animals, and breads. They also have transportation services. For example, there is Ms Sandra who is in a common-law marriage. She is 23 and has two children. Sandra has a store in her house where she works every day selling groceries, meat, vegetables, stationery and books. With the loan Sandra will buy rice, sugar and school supplies. Alejandra is another member, in a common-law marriage, 35 and with 6 children. She also works every day selling cancha (corn kernels used for snacks), pasta, and rice, as a street vendor in front of a mini hospital. Alejandra will use the loan to buy assorted canchas. The members need different loan amounts, like 300 soles, 600 soles, 750 soles, and 1000 soles, for a total of 10,750 soles from the communal bank. Their loans will be used to buy rice, sugar, school supplies, canchas, cereals, cheese, clothing and animals. The dreams of the members are to increase their businesses, for their children to finish their studies, and to have their own homes.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, school supplies, canchas (corn kernels), cereals, cheese, clothing, and small animals

loans.name: Pacaycasa Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Pacaycasa, inicia su ciclo 20 con 19 socias. Las socias son del distrito de Pacaycasa que se ubica a 30 minutos de la ciudad de Ayacucho. 

Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la venta de abarrotes en general, verduras, animales menores, tara, cochinilla, comida, golosinas, ladrillos y frutas.

Como es el caso de la señora Justina que es soltera, tiene 34 años y 1 hijo, Justina se dedica a la compra y venta de tara, cochinilla, tuna, además tiene una tienda de abarrotes en su casa, Justina necesita un préstamo de 600 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de abarrotes.

Mientras que Otilia es conviviente, tiene 36 años y 2 hijos, Otilia vende comida en el campo deportivo de su distrito, actividad que realiza los días domingos, además compra y vende tara, cochinilla. Otilia necesita un préstamo de 900 soles dinero que será invertido en el pago de peones.

Las socias necesitan diferentes montos de prestamos como 300 soles, 600soles, 900 soles  haciendo un total de 12,900 soles de prestamos en el Banco Comunal. 

Sus prestamos serán invertidos en la compra de verduras, tierra, arroz, azúcar, animales menores, tara, cochinilla y para el pago de peones.

Los sueños de las socias son construir su casa, ahorrar para la educación de sus hijos, ampliar sus negocios.
texts.en:
The Pacaycasa group began their 20th loan with 19 members. The group members are from the Pacaycasa district which is located 30 minutes from the city of Ayacucho. The members have different businesses like the sale of groceries, vegetables, small animals, tara, cochinilla, foods, candies, bricks and fruits. As is the case with Señora Justina, who is single and is 34 with one son, Justina buys and sells tara, cochinilla, tuna, and also has a grocery store in her house. Justina needs a loan of 600 soles to invest in the purchase of groceries. While Otilia lives with her partner, she is 36 años and has 2 children, Otilia sells food at the sports field in her district on Sundays, she also buys and sells tara and cochinilla. Otilia needs a loan of 900 soles to pay workers. The group members need different amounts of loans from 300 soles, 600soles, 900 soles making a total of 12,900 soles loans for the group. Their loans will be invested in the purchase of vegetables, dirt, rice, sugar, small animals, tara, cochinilla and to pay employees. The dreams of the group members are to build a house, to save for the education of their children and to improve their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Kelly McKinnon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy vegetables, dirt, rice, sugar, small animals, tara, cochinilla and to pay employees

loans.name: Susana Del Carmen

texts.es: La señora Susana del Carmen P.es casada, tiene dos hijos los cuales son menores de edad, estos están cursando la educación primaria y secundaria, su marido trabaja en una fábrica donde se elaboran tapones, ella se dedica a la venta de Gaseosas, Pan y refrescos naturales, el negocio lo tiene ubicado en la estación de terminal de buses de esta ciudad, tiene 16 años de tener el negocio, y es del negocio y de los ingresos del marido que mantienen a su familia, con la institución trabaja desde el año 2007, en este periodo se le han entregado al cantidad de diez créditos, con los cuales ha trabajado muy responsablemente.
texts.en:
Susana del Carmen P.is married and has two children. They are minors, and they attend elementary school and high school. Her husband works in a factory where they make corks. She sells soft drinks, bread, and natural drinks. Her business is located in the city’s bus terminal. She has had the business for 16 years. The business and her husband’s income support their family. She has worked with the institution since 2007. During this period they have given her ten loans, and she has worked with them very responsibly.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise for her business (Soft drinks, bread, and fruit to make her natural drinks)

loans.name: Zayra Del Socorro

texts.es: Doña Zayra tiene 53 años de edad,  soltera, reside en el barrio 14 de Febrero, procreo nueve hijos los menores a un cursan la primaria,  desde hace diecisiete años se dedica a la venta de tortillas el cual compra el maíz por quintal, y se levanta a horas muy tempranas para ir a moler el maíz que deja ya nesquizado por las noches, para palmear las tortillas en horas de la mañana para vender a sus clientes. Pues da gracias  a Dios por haberle permitido tener su propio negocio ya que durante muchos años trabajo en servicios domesticas el cual el pago era poco y muy cansado. Lo cual ahora ve por su hijo y su casa. Con el crédito  va a comprar  materiales de construcción como: piedra, arena, cemento, zinc para terminar de hacer las divisiones del cuarto ya que su casa es pequeña y sencilla de madera y zinc ya muy viejo pero por falta de dinero no ha logrado estas mejoras para su familia, con el esfuerzo y el interés que tiene de hacer esta necesidad de mejorar los cuarto, el cual espera ir mejorando con cada préstamo que hará en la institución ya que es el medio para poder lograr terminar de reparar su casa ya que le falta levantar las paredes de concreto, cambiar el techo, las puertas y embaldosar ya que es de tierra. Lo cual espera lograr a largo plazo. Y muy contenta por el financiamiento.
texts.en:
Mrs. Zayra is 53, single, and lives in the 14th of February neighborhood. She has nine children, the youngest still in primary school. For the last sixteen years she has worked selling tortillas. She buy the corn by the quintal (46 kilograms), and she gets up very early to grind it. She leaves the corn soaking at night, forms the tortillas in the morning, and then sells them to her customers. She thanks God for having allowed her to have her own business. For many years she worked as a domestic servant, but that work was poorly paid and very tiring. Now she is able to watch over her children and her home. With the loan she will buy construction materials such as: stone, sand, cement, and zinc to finish dividing up the rooms. Her wood and zinc house is small and simple, and now very old. She hasn’t been able to improve the house for her family because of lack of money. With hard work and the interest that she has, she will repair the rooms with each loan from the institution. She needs to build cement walls, change the roof, the doors, and put tile on the dirt floors. She hopes to do all this over a period of time. She is very thankful for the loans.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy constuction materials such as: stone, sand, cement, zinc to divide up the rooms

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy typical dresses and blouses

loans.name: Maria Biviana

texts.es: María Biviana A. G. es de 43 años de edad, tiene 6 hijos, de los cuales sostiene económicamente a 3 de ellos por estar en edad escolar.  Su esposo, el Sr. Jose Eulalio Xajil trabaja en albañilería.  María Biviana hace tortillas todos los días y alquila un local para vender su producto; las personas ya la conocen y le hacen pedidos de canastos llenos de tortilla; además, vende pollo por peso (libras).  Ella solicita el crédito para comprar maíz, leña y gas propano para tener en existencia y seguir haciendo tortillas; su sueño es tener un local propio para no seguir alquilando y agradece a FAPE por la ayuda que recibe, ya que es una institución diferente a las demás instituciones.
texts.en:
María Biviana A. G. is 43 and has six children. She supports three of them because they are school-age. Her husband, Jose Eulalio Xajil, works as a bricklayer. María Biviana makes tortillas everyday. She rents a place to sell her product. People know her and make orders for baskets full of tortillas. She also sells chicken by the pound. She is asking for a loan to buy corn, firewood, and propane gas to have on hand to keep making tortillas. Her dream is to have her own place and to stop renting. She is grateful to FAPE for the help she receives. It is an institution that is different from the other institutions.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy corn, firewood, and propane gas

loans.name: Las Preciosas Group

texts.es:
Cruz C. de 42 años, su esposo es vendedor de llantas en el centro de Guayaquil, con el tiene 4 hijos de 25, 15, 14, 13 años.

Cruz hace 8 años atrás es vendedora ambulante de ropa, zapatos, sabanas y otros, le ayuda su hijo de 25 años. A veces se le hace complicada la transportación de la mercadería pero sigue adelante por su familia.

Con el préstamo quiere comprar más sabanas, zapatos, blusas para tener más variedad en su mercadería.

Cruz es la coordinadora del grupo las Preciosas ella en la foto esta vestida con una blusa floríada en la esquina de la derecha. El grupo las Preciosas viven en una zona periurbana en Paraíso de Guayaquil,  es integrado  por 4 mujeres emprendedoras. Ellas trabajan vendiendo barquillos, ropa, perfumes.

Cruz compartirá este préstamo con el grupo las Preciosas. Ellas mutuamente se han comprometido ser responsables en pagar el préstamo.
texts.en:
Cruz C. is 42. Her husband sells tires in downtown Guayaquil, and together they have 4 children, 25, 15, 14 and 13. 8 years ago she began to work as a street vendor selling clothing, shoes, sheets, and more. Her 25 year-old son helps her. Sometimes she finds it difficult to transport the merchandise but she pushes ahead for her family. With the loan she would like to buy more sheets, shoes, and blouses so that she can have more variety in her merchandise. Cruz is the coordinator of the Preciosas group. She is pictured dressed in a flowered blouse in the corner on the right. The Preciosas group lives in the outskirts of the city of Paraíso de Guayaquil. The group is made up of 4 working women and their businesses are selling ice cream cones, clothing and perfume. Cruz will share this loan with the Preciosas group. They have all agreed to be responsible in the repayment of the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy sheets, shoes, blouses

loans.name: Tesoro Del Triunfo Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal "Tesoro del Triunfo" está conformado por 14 socias, quienes desarrollan sus negocios gracias a los préstamos que reciben del Movimiento Manuela Ramos, se dedican a diferentes actividades y todas sueñan con el progreso de sus familias.

Este Banco Comunal recibió un prestamo inicial de S/.  6,200 soles.

Su presidenta es la señora Irma Tayt, forma parte del Banco Comunal desde hace 1 año.
es una mujer muy dinámica, vive en la región Ucayali, tiene 27 años, es madre de dos menores de edad, ella se dedica a la venta de abarrotes, esta actividad la realiza en su casa y cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo quien trabaja en un chacra cosechando maíz. 

Actualmente las socias requieren de un préstamo de S/ 6,500 soles el cual les permitirá comporar productos diversos al por mayor para sus respectivos negocios.
texts.en:
The Tesoro del Triunfo Communal Bank is comprised of 14 members. They develop their businesses thanks to the loans they receive from the Manuela Ramos Movement. They work at different activities, and all of them dream of family progress. The communal bank’s initial loan was for 6,200 soles. The president is Irma Tayt. She has been part of the communal bank for one year. She is a very dynamic woman, and she lives in the Ucayali area. She is 27 and has two minor children. She sells groceries in her house. She has her husband’s support. He works on a farm harvesting corn. The members currently need a loan for 6,500 soles. This will allow them to buy diverse products wholesale for their respective businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products for their businesses

loans.name: Ada

texts.es:
La Sra. Ada, está casada y tiene 60 años, vive en el Distrito de  Juanjui, Provincia de Mariscal Cáceres, Departamento de San Martín. La Socia pertenece al Banco Comunal “Santa Rosa de Lima” y presenta estudios Superiores de Pedagogía.   Tiene 04 hijos, 01 que aun estudia y depende de ella.

Ada, es una mujer trabajadora, que se siente capaz de cumplir sus  sueños. Desde hace 8 años que se dedica a la venta de abarrotes, y productos de belleza,  siempre contando con el apoyo de su esposo. 
Con su primer crédito de 300 Nuevos Soles, compró: leche en cajas, huevos en jabas, papel higiénico en paquetes, gaseosas en diferentes sabores y tamaños. Y parte del dinero lo invirtió en productos de belleza.

Con este crédito de S/ 2,500.00, comprará arroz y azúcar en sacos, fideos en paquetes, leche y conservas de pescado en cajas y en variedad de marcas,  y productos de belleza como: colonias, talcos, para niños, damas y caballeros, utensilios de aseo para el hogar y de higiene personal para continuar dando una mejor atención a sus clientes. 

Adita, como le dicen de cariño, hoy en día se siente una mujer muy realizada, su sueño es tener un Minimarket bien surtido. Agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudarla a iniciar su negocio y también a muchas mujeres que  quieren crecer empresarialmente.
texts.en:
Ada is 60 years old and married. She lives in Juanjui district, Mariscal Cáceres province, in the Department of San Martín. She is a member of the “Santa Rosa de Lima” communal bank and has university training in the field of education. She has 4 children, one of whom is still studying and dependent on her. Ada is a hard-working woman who feels that she is capable of achieving her dreams. For the past 8 years, she has sold groceries and beauty products, with her husband's constant help and support. With her first loan, for 300 Peruvian new soles, she purchased cases of milk, cartons of eggs, packages of toilet tissue, and soft drinks in various sizes and flavors. She also invested some of the funds in beauty products. With the current loan for 2,500 soles, she will buy sacks of rice and sugar, packages of noodles, milk, and cases of tinned fish of a variety of brands; beauty products for men, women and children, such as colognes and talcum powder; and housecleaning and personal hygiene products, in order to continue satisfying her customers and providing them with better service. "Adita," as those close to her call her, sees herself today as a very fulfilled woman. Her dream is to operate a well-stocked mini-market. She is grateful to the Manuela Ramos Movement organization for helping her start her business, and for also helping many other women who want to grow as entrepreneurs.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing groceries such as rice, sugar, noodles, canned foods, cleaning and hygiene products, and beauty products

loans.name: Rosa Maria

texts.es:
La Sra. Rosa, tiene 38 años, vive en el Distrito de Juanjui, Provincia de Mariscal Cáceres , Departamento de San Martin , la socia  pertenece al Banco Comunal “Santa Rosa de Lima” , presenta estudios de secundaria completa  y tiene 03 hijos , 01  que aun estudia y depende de ella .

Rosa, se dedica a la venta de Comidas Preparadas y lleva 05 años en el negocio, se encuentra ubicada en  su misma casa  un lugar muy amplio y acondicionado para atender a sus clientes que diariamente acuden. Nos cuenta que a diario tiene muy buenas ventas, por la sazón rica que le da a sus preparados, es conocida y tiene muy buena acogida. Con su primer crédito de 300 Nuevos Soles compró ingredientes para el preparado de sus comidas como, arroz en kilos, menestras, verduras, aceite y parte del dinero lo invirtió en utensilios.  

En la actualidad, continúa con el mismo negocio y esta muy contenta con su trabajo que realiza. Es ella quien personalmente atiende a sus clientes con el carisma y amabilidad que le caracteriza.

Con este crédito  de S/ 1,000.00, comprará insumos para la preparación diaria de sus alimentos como arroz en kilos, aceites en litros, pollos en javas, verduras y también  algunos utensilios, para dar una mejor atención a sus clientes. 

Rosita como le dicen de cariño , se siente llena de vida y con ganas de seguir adelante, su sueño es tener un restaurant  y implementar su propia tienda de abarrotes, muy bien  acondicionado y al mismo tiempo también agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por contribuir  en iniciar su negocio.
texts.en:
Mrs. Rosa is 38, and lives in the Juanjui District, in the Mariscal Cáceres Province, San Martin Department. This member belongs to the communal bank “Santa Rosa de Lima”. She finished secondary school and has 3 children, 1 who is still in school and is her dependent. Rosa has been working selling prepared food for 5 years. She sells from her house in a roomy and well-arranged area, where she can take care of the customers who come every day. She tells us that she has good daily sales, because her tasty food is well-known and very popular. With her first loan of 300 new soles, she bought ingredients to prepare her food, such as kilos of rice, vegetable stew, vegetables, and oil, and part of the money she spent on cooking utensils. She continues in the same business and is very happy with the way the work has turned out. She is the one who personally takes care of her customers, with the charisma and cheerfulness that characterize her. With this loan of 1,000.00 soles, she will buy ingredients for the daily preparation of her food, such as kilos of rice, liters of cooking oil, quantities of chickens, vegetables, and also some utensils to help her better attend to her customers. Her affectionate nickname is Rosita. She is full of life and with a desire to get ahead. Her dream is to have a restaurant and start her own well-stocked grocery store. She thanks the Manuela Ramos Movement for helping in starting her own business.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients to prepare her food: kilos of rice, liters of cooking oil, quantities of chickens, vegetables and some cooking utensils

loans.name: Elena

texts.es:
La Sra. Elena, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Santa Rosa de Lima”, Distrito de Juanjui, Provincia de Mariscal Cáceres, Departamento de San Martín. Es conviviente, tiene 40 años y es madre de 03 hijos, 01 que aun depende de ella y esta estudiando. La socia presenta estudios hasta tercer año de secundaria.

Elena, es una mujer alegre, perseverante y capaz de salir adelante, nos cuenta que poco a poco ha ido cumpliendo sus  metas y sueños, siempre contando con el apoyo de su esposo.
Con su primer crédito de 500 Nuevos Soles compró: camisas , blusas, en todas las tallas y modelos , para damas, caballeros y niños, en la actualidad se dedica a venta de ropas usadas, tiene clientes fijos que la conocen y saben de su negocio que se encuentra ubicado en su misma casa, un lugar muy bien acondicionado.

Con este crédito de S/. 3,000.00, comprará prendas de vestir como: pantalones, shorts, snikers, blusas en todas las tallas y modelos, polos y vestidos para niñas. 

Elna nos dice: "Agradezco la oportunidad que me ofrece el Movimiento  Manuela Ramos,  de contar con los préstamos que me ayudan a desarrollarme como mujer y pequeña empresaria".
texts.en:
Mrs Elena is 40, and lives in the Juanjui District, in the Mariscal Cáceres Province, San Martin Department. This member belongs to the communal bank “Santa Rosa de Lima”. She is in a common-law marriage and has 3 children, 1 who is still in school and is her dependent. She herself went up to third year in secondary school. Elena is a happy, persevering woman who is capable of getting ahead. She tells us that little by little she has been fulfilling her goals and dreams, always being able to count on her husband’s support. With her first loan of 500 new soles, she bought: shirts, blouses in all the sizes and styles, for women, men and children. She is currently working selling used clothing. She has regular customers who know her and know about her business. It is located in her own home, in a well arranged area. With this 3,000.00 new soles loan, she will buy clothing such as:pants, shorts, sneakers, blouses in all sizes and styles, polo shirts and girls’ dresses. Elena tells us:”I appreciate the opportunity that the Maneula Ramos Movement offers me, that I can count on the loans to help me develop as a woman and small entrepreneur".

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing wholesale to supply her business

loans.name: Reidelinda

texts.es:
La Sra. Reidelinda, tiene 63 años, vive en el Distrito de Juanjui, Provincia de Mariscal Cáceres, Departamento de San Martín. La socia pertenece al Banco Comunal “Santa Rosa de Lima” y presenta estudios hasta segundo grado de primaria, es viuda, tiene 4 hijos todos ya independientes. 
Reidelinda lleva 10 años dedicándose al negocio de frutas, se encuentra ubicado en un mercado cerca de su casa.
Con su primer crédito de 300 Nuevos Soles compró naranjas en cientos, limones en sacos y plátanos en racimos.
Con este crédito de S/. 2,000.00, Nuevos Soles comprará frutas cómo: naranjas en cientos, carambolas (fruta silvestre de la selva), plátanos de seda, piñas, guayabas brasileras, etc. Y así satisfacer a su clientela, que día a día acuden a su puesto de ventas.
Reidelinda, se siente muy contenta por el trabajo que realiza, el buen producto que vende le ha proporcionado clientela fiel. La Socia sueña con tener su local propio en su casa. Agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por el apoyo que le brindan a ella y a otras mujeres más que lo necesitan, en iniciar e implementar su negocio.
texts.en:
Reidelinda, 63, lives in the Juanjui district, Mariscal Cásceres province, San Martín department. She belongs to the Santa Rosa de Lima Communal Bank. She has a second grade education. She is a widow, and she has four independent children. Reilinda has been in the business of selling fruit for ten years. Her business is located in the market close to her house. With her first loan for 300 PEN she bought oranges by the hundreds, sacks of lemons, and bunches of bananas. With this loan for 2,000 PEN she will buy fruit like oranges by the hundreds, “carambolas” (a wild jungle fruit), plantains, pineapples, and Brazilian guavas, etc. That way she will satisfy her customers who come to her stand day to day. Reilinda is very happy with the work she does. The good product that she sells has given her loyal customers. The member dreams of having her own place to sell from in her house. She is grateful to the Manuela Ramos Movement for the support they give her, and other women who need it, to start and establish their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fruits to stock her business

loans.name: Fabian

texts.en: Fabian has been a New York City cab driver for nine years. Knowing that his current cab needed upgrading to meet more rigorous safety requirements, Fabian's family urged him to contact ACCION USA for a micro-loan. Fabian’s loan will be used to purchase a new car, without which he would lose his livelihood. Since both Fabian's family in New York and his relatives in his native Ecuador rely on his income, Fabian is very glad that he was able to get the financing needed to keep his business afloat. While he was able to learn how to navigate New York City streets on his own, he credits ACCION USA with helping him navigate the US financial system. Fabian hopes to eventually save enough money to buy a house here, and realize his own American Dream. About U.S. Microfinance and ACCION USA: Have you ever thought about how the cute new café on your corner or the salon you frequent every month got the financial resources to start their business? Chances are, they drummed up support from their friends and family, dipped into their personal savings, used a high-interest credit card, or all of the above. An estimated ten million small businesses in the U.S. face difficulty obtaining loans from traditional banks, even prior to the current “credit crisis”. Microfinance institutions, like ACCION USA, support these “unbanked” small businesses by giving them access to fairly-priced capital and business education. Small businesses also help stabilize low- to moderate-income neighborhoods and rebuild our economy through income growth and job creation. Self-employment provides workers with a way to increase their incomes, support their families, and strengthen their communities. As unemployment rises in the U.S., more and more people are turning to self-employment and start-up enterprises as a way to take control of their economic futures and provide employment opportunities in their communities. The need for support of small businesses in the U.S. is great, and it is one that ACCION USA has been striving to meet since 1991.

loans.use: To buy a newer taxicab

loans.name: Marta

texts.es:
La Sra. Marta, tiene 43 años, vive en el Distrito de Juanjui, Provincia de Mariscal Caceres, Departamento de San Martín. La Socia pertenece al Banco Comunal “Santa Rosa de Lima”, y estudió primaria completa, es conviviente, tiene 05 hijos, 02 que aun dependen de ella y están estudiando.

Su fuerza y anhelo de sacar adelante a sus hijos, la motivaron a emprender su propio negocio de venta de abarrotes, que se encuentra ubicado en su misma casa en un ambiente muy bien acondicionado. 
Las ganancias que genera a diario, la ayuda al ingreso económico en su familia. 

Con su primer crédito de 300 Nuevos Soles compró, variedad de detergentes, jabones de tocador,  conservas de pescado, etc. Desde su  inicio a la fecha ha ido ganando clientes y en la actualidad tiene clientes fijos que a diario acuden a su casa a comprar y es ella quien personalmente les atiende  con el carisma que le caracteriza.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000.00, comprará conservas de pescado en cajas y en variedad de marcas, té en cajas de diferentes sabores (manzanilla, canela y clavo, anís), detergente, huevos en javas y artículos de higiene personal para continuar dando una mejor atención a sus clientes. 

Marta, se siente con mucha fortaleza para continuar trabajando y prepararse para hacer frente a las adversidades de la vida.
Agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudar a mujeres como ella a tener oportunidades de desarrollarse como microempresarias.
texts.en:
Marta, 43, lives in the Juanjui district, Mariscal Caceres province, San Martín department. The member belongs to the Santa Rosa de Lima Communal Bank. She has an elementary school education, and she is in a common law marriage. She has five children; two of them are dependent upon her and go to school. Her strength and desire to get her children ahead motivated her to undertake her own business selling groceries. Her business is located in her house in a very well equipped area. The earnings that are generated daily help with the family income. With her first loan for 300 PEN she bought a variety of detergents, bars of soap, and canned fish, etc. From the start up until now she has been gaining customers. She currently has fixed customers who come to her house to shop daily. She personally waits on them with her characteristic charisma. With this loan for 1,000 PEN she will buy cases of different varieties and brands of canned fish, boxes of different flavors (chamomile, cinnamon and clove, anis) tea, detergent, crates of eggs, and personal hygiene products. She will buy these things to continue giving great attention to her customers. Marta has a lot of strength to continue working and prepare herself to get in front of life’s adversities. She is grateful to the Manuela Ramos Movement for helping women like her have opportunities to develop themselves as small businesswomen.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy groceries to stock her store

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.es:
La socia tiene 30 años, es conviviente y tiene dos hijos (Gabriela tiene 12 años y Julio Cesar tiene 10 años). La socia se levanta muy temprano para hacer sus actividades del hogar como por ejemplo preparar desayuno para sus hijos. La socia y su esposo tienen un taller de carpintería donde fabrican muebles como mesas, roperos y sillas. Ya son ocho años que se dedica al negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo. Ella requiere el préstamo para comprar más materiales como madera y clavos. 

Ella pertenece al banco comunal “Las hijas de Maria” de la Asociación Arariwa y se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
The member is 30 years old, lives with a partner, and has 2 children: Gabriela, who is 12, and Julio Cesar, who is 10. She gets up very early to perform her household chores; for example, to prepare breakfast for her children. She and her husband have a carpentry workshop where they make furniture such as tables, wardrobes and chairs. They have had this business for 8 years and it has gone very well, thanks to all of the effort they put into their work. She needs a loan to buy more materials such as wood and nails. She belongs to the communal bank "Las Hijas de Maria," which is part of the Asociación Arariwa. She is grateful for the opportunity provided through these means, and likewise she pledges to make her payments according to the established timeline.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy materials such as wood and nails

loans.name: Silvia

texts.es:
Silvia tiene 50 años, es madre soltera y tiene tres hijos. La socia nos cuenta que su hija Maria Milagros tiene 29 años y es discapacitada, Silvia la mayor parte de su tiempo se dedica a cuidar a su hija. Silvia se levanta muy temprano para hacer sus actividades del hogar como por ejemplo preparar desayuno para sus hijos y muchas cosas más. Silvia es una mujer luchadora que saca adelante a sus hijos pues hace la labor de padre y madre. La socia tiene un pequeño negocio de confeccionar muñecas de tela y los sábados los vende en la feria de la plaza “Tupac Amaru” del distrito de Wanchaq de la ciudad del Cusco. Ya son dos a tres años que se dedica al negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo. Silvia requiere el préstamo para comprar más materiales como tela y lana.

Silvia pertenece al banco comunal “Las hijas de Maria” de la Asociación Arariwa y se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Silvia is 50 years old and a single mother with three children. Her daughter Maria Milagros is 29 years old and disabled, so Silvia spends most of her time taking care of her. She wakes up very early to perform her household activities, such as preparing breakfast for her children and many other tasks. Silvia is a woman who struggles to raise her children since she must be both mother and father to them.

She has a small business manufacturing cloth dolls and selling them at the Tupac Amaru Fair in the District of Wanchaq, located in the city of Cusco. She already has 2-3 years experience in this business and has done very well because of her hard work. Silvia is requesting a loan to buy more materials, such as fabric and wool.

She is a member of the Communal Bank “Las Hijas de Maria” (The Daughters of Mary), which is part of Asociación Arariwa. Silvia is grateful for this opportunity and promises to make her payments on time.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fabric and wool for making dolls

loans.name: Trabajando Para El Mañana Ii Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal "Trabajando para el mañana II", está conformado por 16 socias, todas muy emprendedoras y trabajadoras.   Viven en el distrito D. Callería, región Ucayali y sus negocios son variados, desD. la compra y venD. D. productos D. abarrotes, hasta la venta D. cosméticos.

Su primer crédito fue D. 6,300 soles con el cual las socias pudieron comprar sus productos para abastecer sus negocios.

Su presidenta es la Sra. Biqui Melita, es una mujer muy trabajadora, vive en el Distrito D.  Calleria, región Ucayali, tiene 30 años, madre D. dos menores D. edad, ella se dedica a administrar su negocio, cuenta con el apoyo D. su esposo quien es chofer D. motocar.  Ella es coia D. este Banco Comunal desD. hace un año y medio.  La meta D. Biqui Melita, es tener una discoteca en la maloca que posee  y poner su tienD..

Actualmente este Banco requiere D. un préstamo D. S/. 6,900 soles, que será invertido en los diferentes negocios.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank "Trabajando para el Mañana II" (Working for Tomorrow II) consists of sixteen members. All of them are enterprising and hardworking women. They live in the District of Callería in the region of Ucayali and operate various retail businesses selling products such as groceries and cosmetics.

The group president is Sra. Biqui Melita, a hardworking woman from the District of Calleria. She is 30 years old and a mother with two dependent children. Biqui manages her business and has the support of her husband, who is a motorcycle taxi driver. She has been a member of this Communal Bank for 1½ years. Her dreams are to open a discothèque in the “maloca” (an ancestral long house) that she owns and establish a store.

At the moment, the entire Communal Bank is requesting a loan of 6900 soles to invest in their various businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital for their respective businesses

loans.name: 21 De Junio Group

texts.es:
9 mujeres y 1 varon son los integrantes de la Asociación Comunal 21 de Junio. Sus negocios son diversos: venta de chinelas, tienda de mantas, macramé, elaboración de artesanìas, tienda de mantas, venta de comida y comerciante en ropa. 

Una de ellas, Claudia Gutierres tiene un negocio de venta de zapatos, sandalias y pantuflas para niños;  cuando inicio su negocio ella era soltera y su objetivo era lograr un ingreso propio para estudiar, al princio le ayudó su mamá.  Su puesto es fijo en la Zona 16 de Julio de la Ciudad de El Alto.  

Ella considera que con el dinero que está solicitando podrá comprar aproximadamente 8 docenas en  mercadería, comenta que es necesario surtir el negocio con diferentes tipos de zapatos, sandalias y pantuflas y en diferentes tamaños.

Actualmente la señora Claudia Gutierres se encuentra casada y tiene un niño pequeño.  Piensa que a sus veintidos años es mejor por el momento no tener mas hijos y espera consultar con la médico de Pro Mujer para ser orientada en el mejor método anticonceptivo.
texts.en:
The June 21st Communal Bank consists of nine women and one man. They have different retail businesses selling slippers, blankets, macramé, handicrafts, rugs, food, and clothing.

One of the members is Claudia G.. She operates a home business selling shoes, sandals, and slippers for children. When she started her business, Claudia was single and earning money in order to pay for her own education. Her mother helped with the business at the very beginning. Her vending location is established in the July 16th District of the City of El Alto.

She plans to use the money she requested to buy 8 dozen units of merchandise. Claudia says it is necessary to restock her business with various types of shoes, sandals, and slippers in different sizes.

Sra. Claudia is currently married and has a young child. She believes being in her twenties is a good time to have more children, so she is waiting to consult with one of the doctors at Pro Mujer to determine the best method of contraception.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital for their respective businesses

loans.name: Maggi Isabel

texts.es:
Maggi Isabel B. tiene 20 años, llegó con sus padres y su hermano hace alrededor de 15  años desde Casacará, Departamento del Cesar; desde muy niña la necesidad la hizo pensar en generar ingresos porque no pudo seguir viviendo en el pueblo donde naciò, ya que el miedo de muchos de sus habitantes entre los que se cuentan su familia, los llevò a abandonar su tierra natal para llegar  a  Soledad, donde  encontrò instituciones internacionales que en su infancia le estimularon el habito de estudio, cuando le regalaron utiles escolares y libro de cuentos.  En ese entonces su madre apoyaba las campañas de alfabetizaciòn y ayudaba a mujeres en el cuidado y la complementacion de actividades acadèmicas de sus hijos, para generar algunos ingresos con el apoyo de Maggui; ese precisamente fuè el origen de un pequeño colegio en proceso de normatizaciòn  de su madre en el barrio Nuevo Milenio del Municipio de Soledad y donde Maggi tambien trabaja parte de su tiempo, pues es una joven muy productiva.   
Maggi tiene su propio negocio que iniciò con la ayuda de un programas de gobierno  el cual iniciò con un computador que aprendiò a operarlo; luego accediò a un crédito con la misma entidad para comprar otros equipos mas y aceder a la red de internet para luego gradualmente adicionar una fotocopiadora, una máquina reveladora y una máquina fotográfica. Al principio con un computador en su casa y muchos libros pestaba servicios bibliotecarios de consulta en el barrio,a estudiantesen en su barrio, donde la mayoria de vecinos son desplazados por el conflicto armado como su familia. Aunque parece que para Maggi eso es hoy parte de la historia, porque ella no quiere regresar a Casacará, como han hecho muchos de sus habitantes apoyados por el estado para su retorno;dice  que con sus negocios, ella y su mamà han logrado salir adelante, ayudar a su hermano menor y apoyar el ingreso de su padre al hogar, lo cual le ha proporcionado cierta estabilidad.
Maggi, al mismo tiempo que trabaja siempre ha estudiado y desde el nivel de educaciòn secundaria se ha enfocado en la pedagogia; actualmente estudia licenciatura en eduaciòn bàsica en la Universidad del Atlàntico; ella està en la busqueda de ganarse un escalafon en el sistema Educativo formal y por eso dia a dia se esfuerza por estudiar, asi como lo hizo cuando con su mami a clases, preparandose juntas para tener herramientas pedagogicas aplicables a su trabajo en el colegio; permitiendole a su madre cuidarla de cerca pues terminò el bachillerato a los 15 años. 
Maggi es una joven polifacètica le encanta el arte de fotografiar, por eso en su local ademàs de hacer fotomontajes, fotos para documentos y de tipo social, por ejemplo fotografias de bautizos, cumpleaños primeras comuniones etc. ayuda a la gente a acceder a la tencologia de internet y a hacer trasncripciones para presenter curriculos de trabajo, o para averiguar informaciòn de algun programa al que estan aplicando,  ya que en  esta comunidad  no es muy usual que la gente conozca el manejo de las herramientas de informatica y mucho menos tenga una red de internet personal a su disposicion y es menos comun saber acceder a ella. 
El negocio principal de Maggi es una sala de internet, donde ademas presta el servicio de fotocopiado, fotografia, fotomontaje, colajes para los niños, redacciones y transcripciones. Ella es una joven ejemplar, por su gran sentido de responsabilidad, su capacidad de trabajar y estudiar desarrollada desde muy niña  y su disposicion para acceder a los servicios que fortalecen su crecimiento personal y empresarial; asi fuè cuando le recomendaron ir a la Fundaciòn Mario Santo Domingo para obtener un crèdito que incrementara su capital de trabajo y para recibir asesorìa para formalizar su pequeño negocio a lo que ella inmediatamente accediò y en la actualidad su asesor Milgen Sanchez la està asesorando en este tràmite .
Con el actual y su primer credito por valor de $1.500.000, Maggi planea ampliar su negocio adecuando su sala de internet para tomar fotografias, hacer pendones publicitarios, con el fin de ser mas conocida por otras comunidades  cercanas. Ella considera que su negocio es muy estable, no tiene competencia en el barrio, por eso sus clientes muchas veces esperan en su puerta hasta que otro termine de acceder al servicio por el que vino al negocio.
Su principal desafio que es el de todos en la familia, trabajar intensamente para apoyar el tratamiento de su padre que sufrio un Accidente de trabajo y su programa de salud no alcanza a cubrir los medicamentos  que requiere para superar la situaciòn. De igual manera sueña con ayudar a su hermano a que desarrolle sus potencialidades y estudie en la universidad la carrera que le guste; mientras tanto ella sueña con subir de escalafon  en el sistema educativo y legalizar el colegio de su madre
Maggi  y su mama, describen su barrio, Nuevo Milenio, como una comunidad donde la mayoria son  desplazados, pero muy por encima de eso son gente solidaria y trabajadora; explica  que tuvieron que organizarse para que sus calles pasaran de ser un basurero a lo que es hòy,  ya que fuè producto de una invasion que el estado esta legalizando; sostiene que entre todos han contribuido a poner servicios publicos comunitarios  y  que a travès de su negocio contribuye a llevar tecnologia a los hogares mas pobres, pues son muchos, los que aun no tienen posibilidades de acceder a la redes de Internet y de conocer el manejo de la informatica.
texts.en:
Maggi Isabel B. is 20. She arrived from Casacará in the Cesar department with her parents and brother about 15 years ago. Ever since she was a little girl necessity make her think of generating income. She could not continue living in the town where she was born because of the fear of some of its inhabitants. This caused her to abandon the place where she was born and go to Soledad. There she found international institutions that encouraged her to study by giving her school supplies and a book of stories. At that time her mother supported the literacy campaigns, and she helped women in the care and completion of the academic activities of their children. She did this with Maggi’s help to generate some income. This was the start of a small school, which was part of her mother’s adjustment to the Nuevo Milenio neighborhood in the municipality of Soledad. Maggi also worked there part time; she is a very productive young woman. Maggi has her own business, which she started with the help of a government program. She started with a computer, which she learned to operate. Then she got a loan with the same entity to buy other equipment and access the Internet. Then she gradually added a photocopier, a developing machine, and a photography machine. At first she used a computer and a lot of books to offer librarian services from her house to neighborhood students. Most of the neighbors are displaced due to the armed conflict, just like her family. Although it may appear to be part of the story, Maggi does not want to return to Casacará like many people, who are supported by the state, have done. She says that with their businesses she and her mother have gotten ahead, helped her younger brother, and helped with the income her father brings home. This has given them some stability. At the same time that Maggi has worked she has always gone to school. She has been focusing on pedagogy since high school. She is currently studying for her degree in basic education from the Atlantic University. She is looking to win a place in the formal education system. Therefore, she studies hard everyday, just like she did with her mother. They prepared themselves together to have the pedagogy tools that applied to their work in the school. This allowed her mother to be close and take care of her. Magi got her high school degree at 15. Maggi is a multi-faceted young woman. She loves the art of photography. At her place she does more than photo montages, photos for documents, and social photos. For example, she does baptism photos, birthdays, and communions, etc. She helps people access the technology of the internet, make job resumes, or to find information about a program they are using. It is unusual in this community for the people to know how to use information tools, and even less common for them to have the use of the internet at their disposal. It is less likely that they know how to access the internet. Maggi’s main business is a large internet café, where she also offers photocopy, photography, photo montage, collages for children, editing, and transcription services. She is an exemplary young woman because of her great sense of responsibility, her work capacity, her studies since childhood, and her aptitude for accessing the services that strengthen her personal and business growth. That is how it was when they recommended that she go to the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation to get a loan to increase her working capital and to get an advisor to formalize her small business. She immediately got a counselor, Milgen Sanchez, who is currently advising her in this procedure. Maggi plans to expand her business using her current first loan for 1,500,000 COP. She will equip her internet café with the ability to take photos and make publicity banners. She will do this to become better known in nearby communities. She considers her business to be very stable. She does not have competition in the neighborhood, and many times her neighbors wait at her door for their turn to get the services they wish to access. Her main challenge is the same as with all families. She works intensely to support her father’s treatment. He suffered a work accident, and his health program does not cover the medications he needs to overcome the situation. She also dreams of helping her brother develop his potential and study for a career he would like in the university. Meanwhile, she dreams of climbing the ladder in the educational system and legalizing her mother’s school. Maggi and her mother describe their neighborhood, Nuevo Milenio, as a community where most are displaced. But, underneath it all, they are united and hard-working people. She explains that they had to organize themselves so that their streets would stop being a garbage dump into what it is now. It was a product of an invasion that the state is legalizing. Everyone has contributed to establishing community public services. Through her business she is contributing to bringing technology to the poorest homes. There are a lot of people who still cannot access the internet and do not know how to work with computers.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Equip her photographic space and invest in publicity, especially banners that she designs

loans.name: Lesbia Del Socorro

texts.es: Lesbia Del Carmen tiene 33 años de edad, por lo que su actividad económica es la compra y venta de sal, además de dedicarse a este negocio ella vende teja que son productos muy útiles en estos departamentos, porque la mayoría de las personas cuando construyen sus casas lo realizan con materiales favorables y las tejas son unos de los productos importantes. Pero actualmente su negocio más potencial es la venta de sal, por lo que es una mujer muy emprendedora y además les ha proporcionado a sus 2 hijos lo necesario para que pudieran estudiar y tener las posibilidades necesarias. Ella solicita este financiamiento para invertirlo en su negocio ya que se aproxima una buena temporada. Su deseo es salir adelante y seguirse superando.
texts.en:
Lesbia Del Carmen is 33 years old. Her economic activity is buying and selling salt. In addition to this business, she also sells shingles, which are very useful products in these regions, because most people build their houses with good materials, and shingles are one of the main products they need. However, selling salt is currently her most successful business. She is a very enterprising woman who has provided her 2 children with everything they need to get an education and enjoy good opportunities. She is requesting the current loan in order to invest the funds in her business, since a favorable season is coming up. Her desire is to get ahead and continue making progress.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es:
Carmen Jimenez C., tiene 70 años, vive en su casa del barrio Ciudadela Metropolitana , urbanizaciòn apoyada por la Fundaciòn Mario Santo Domingo hace mas de 20 años en la construcciòn de su comunidad.   Carmen es una mujer alegre y dicharachera, bien conocida en el barrio por sus vecinos, tiene 4 hijos en edades de 46 a 57 años, a ella antes de casarse siempre le gustò el negocio, es la propia mujer sucreña expontanea y trabajadora que conocen muy bien el ganado, base ecconòmica de su tierra natal, el suero atoyabuey o suero costeño, el bollo dulce y el diabolin. Desde muy niña trabajò,fue empleada domèstica,vendiò mercancia al pormayor, alquilò un puesto en el mercado, hacia de todo un poco con tal de adecuar su casa con muebles y electròdomesticos para vivir bien y poder traerse uno por uno de sus hijos desde la hermosa sabana de Sucre y brindarles una mejor forma de vivir bajo los principios de honestidad y responsabilidad.  
Cuando Maicao-Guajira, municipio ubicado en la frontera con Venezuela, tuvo su mejor auge comercial, ella viajaba constantemente traia mercancia al por mayor que vendia en las chazas o puestos del mercado y a otros vendedores ambulantes, pero cuando se casò su esposo no quiso que siguiera viajando y le consiguio un puesto en el mercado donde vendiò sopas-sancochos, aunque nunca dejo de comercializar con mercancias y aguzar el ingenio para conseguir el diario sustento con lo que la clientela le pedia, asi tambien trabajò la elaboraciòn de ropa interior femenina y comprò sus maquinas para esa tarea, esto le costò que su esposo la apodara, "La 7 negocios" pues siempre ha hecho de todo un poco como ella lo expresa.
En la actualidad vive con su hija que trabaja en el hospital y con sus nietos, ella es emprendedora "no le gusta esperar que le den dinero", es autosuficiente y "si le prestan de sus ahorritos deben pagarle correctamente" asi enseñò a sus hijos y sus nietos ven ese ejemplo, por eso con orgullo dice que ha podido ayudar a su familia, como cuando le prestò dinero a su nieto para pagar su carrera de policia, Carmen dice que "èl es muy serio"  y lo devolverà  a su cuenta de ahorros, cuando regrese ya graduado y asi "la platica-$- sigue en buenas manos". 
Los 2 creditos que ha tenido con la Fundaciòn, le han servido para generar nuevos negocios ampliar y fortalecer su vida comercial y crediticia, porque ahora la llaman de los Bancos para ofrecerle crèdito, pero ella solo tiene el de la Fundaciòn que en la actualidad es por valor de $1.000.000 y lo usarà para comprar sillas plàsticas y  telas para la elaboraciòn de ropa intima femenina que le encargan. Su gran sueño es “SEGUIR CON VIDA” porque a los 70 años eso es lo màximo que una persona puede perdirle a Dios, por eso desea continuar fuerte y saludable para “no estirar la pata como” como  ella dice en su coloquial lenguaje.
texts.en:
Carmen Jimenez C. is 70 years old and lives in the Ciudadela Metropolitana neighborhood whose construction has been supported by the Fundacion Mario Santo Domingo for the last 20 years. Carmen is a very happy and witty woman who is well known by her neighbors. She has 4 children ranging from 46 to 57 years old. Before she got married, she always liked working. This very spontaneous, hard-working woman worked for some time in the business very common in her home city--raising livestock. She has worked since she was very young--working as a maid, selling wholesale merchandise, renting a locale in the market--she did a little bit of everything in order to provide furniture and appliances for her home and to raise her children, providing them with a better standard of living while instilling principles of honesty and responsibility. When Maicao-Guajira, the town on the Venezuelan border, was at the height of its economic boom, she traveled constantly bringing wholesale merchandise that she sold in the markets or to other door-to-door salesmen, but when she got married, her husband didn't want her to keep traveling so she got a locale in the market where she sold soups. Nonetheless, she didn't stop selling merchandise and sharpening her ingenuity to provide for her clientele and find new ways to earn income. She began making women's underwear and purchased sewing machines to do her work, this caused her husband to dub her "The woman of 7 businesses." Currently, she lives with her daughter, who works in the hospital, and with her grandchildren. She is very enterprising and she doesn't like to wait for people to give her money. She is self-sufficient and taught her children and grandchildren by word and example, "if someone lends you money from their savings, you should pay them back punctually." She proudly has provided for her family and when she lent money to her grandson so he could go to school to become a police officer, she said, "He is very reliable and will put it in his savings account; when he graduates, he will be able to say, 'The money was in good hands.'" She has used the two loans from the Foundation to create new business and enlarge and strengthen her many enterprises; now banks call her to offer her loans but she only seeks loans from the Foundation--this current loan is for $525 which she will use to buy plastic chairs and cloth to fulfill her orders of women's underwear. Her dream is to always "Keep on living" because at 70 years old, it is the greatest thing one can ask for from God--to continue strong and healthy, and not "kick the bucket."

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase cloth to make underwear and other merchandise

loans.name: Gregorio

texts.es: El señor Gregorio Dávila, vive en el Barrio 31 de diciembre tiene 58 años y tiene 5 hijos y todos trabajan de forma independiente y le apoyan económicamente, él sobrevive gracias a su negocio el cual es una pulpería y la cual le es muy rentable y es gracias a los créditos, que anteriormente le han otorgado, es que la venta se mantiene prospera, con las ganancias que le han generado estas, ha podido comprar su moto y un carro, tiene el objetivo de invertirle nuevamente al negocio para convertirlo en una miscelánea y generar mejores ingresos, esto le ayudaría a llevar a cabo proyectos que tiene el señor Dávila en mente y al crecimiento continuo de sus condicione económicas y sociales.
texts.en:
Gregorio D. lives in the December 31st neighborhood, is 58 years old and has 5 children who all work independently and support their father economically. He gets by thanks to his business which is a small store that he runs; it is very profitable and thanks to the loans he has received, he has been able to keep it prospering and been able to buy himself a motorcycle and car. He would like to continue investing in the business to make it a small general store and generate greater income. This will help him carry out projects he has planned and help him improve his economic and social standard of living.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase more inventory for his business

loans.name: Juan Nerio

texts.es:
Juan tiene 50 años, es divorciado y tiene dos hijas (Maria Luisa tiene 17 años y Katherine tiene 9 años). Nuestro socio trabaja como chofer en una empresa privada y también alquila habitaciones de su domicilio.  El socio es un padre trabajador y emprendedor que saca adelante a su familia. Ya son dos años que se dedica alquilar habitaciones y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo su esfuerzo que pone en su labor. El socio requiere el préstamo para hacer mantenimiento de las habitaciones y para el gasto familiar. El socio se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.

Juan pertenece al banco comunal “Las hijas de Maria” de la Asociación Arariwa.
texts.en:
Juan is 50 years old, divorced and has 2 daughters (Maria Luise is 17 years old and Katherine is 9 years old). He works as a driver in a private business and rents rooms in his home. He is a very hard-working and enterprising father who strives to support his family. He has rented rooms of his home for the past 2 years and it has gone very well thanks to the effort he puts in. He is seeking this loan to perform maintenance on the rooms and for family expenses. He is very grateful for the opportunity he is receiving through this loan and commits to pay according to the timeline. Juan belongs to the "Maria's Daughters" village bank of the Arariwa Association.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Perform maintenance on his rented rooms and for family expenses

loans.name: Las Triunfadoras De Marco Jara Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal "LAS TRIUNFADORAS D. MARCO JARA", D. Distrito D. Yarina coha, región Ucayali, está conformado por 10 socias.  Su primer préstamo fue D. 5,700 soles, dinero que permitió a las socias a implementar sus negocios.

Su presidneta es la señora Enith C. E., ella es una mujer muy laboriosa, vive en el Distrito D. Yarina cocha, región Ucayali, tiene 39 años, es madre D. tres menores D. edad, se dedica al sembrío D. camu camu (fruta D. la región), esta actividad la realiza en su chacra y cuenta con el apoyo D. su esposo quien es mecanico. La meta D. Enith es, tener un Minimarket y mas adelante un supermercado, en donD. se venda sus productos. 

Actualmente, requieren D. un préstamo D. S/ 4,600 soles, las socias utilizarán su crédito en los diferentes negocios que tienen, permitiendo que se desarrollen economicamente.
texts.en:
The communal bank "Las Triunfadoras D. Marco Jara," from the Yarina Coha district in the Ucayali region, is maD. up of 10 members. Their first loan was for 5,700 Peruvian soles, money that the members used to carry out their businesses. Their president is Enith C. E.; she is a hardworking woman who lives in the Yarina Cocha district in the Ucayali region. She is 39 years old and is the mother of 3 minor children. She cultivates camu camu (a native fruit of the region.) She carries out this activity on her farm and she has the support of her husband, who is a mechanic. Enith's goal is to have a Minimarket, and eventually, a supermarket, where she can sell her products. Currently they need a loan of 4,600 Peruvian soles. They will use this loan in the different businesses that they have, allowing them to develop economically.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: they will use the loan in the different businesses that they have

loans.name: Neil Tamaris

texts.es: La señora Neil Tamaris M. C., es madre de un niño de 2 años, es casada de 41 años de edad vive en la ciudad de Managua y su marido trabaja como distribuidor independiente de productos Diana y ella lo acompaña distribuyendo el producto en los diferentes Barrios de la Capital, ellos Habitan en el Barrio Laureles Norte, dentro de las dificultades que ha tenido estos años ha sido la delincuencia que se vive en los Barrios de Managua, ella solicita un préstamo para comprar más inventario y de esta forma elevar los volúmenes de venta y generar mas ingresos que agranden el capital del negocio, esto le permitiría a la familia mejores condiciones de vida y solidez para futuros proyectos.
texts.en:
Mrs. Neil Tamaris is married, 41 years old, and the mother of a 2 year old boy. She lives in the city of Managua and her husband works as an independent distributor of Diana products. She accompanies him in distributing the products in the different barrios of the capital. They live in Laureles Norte barrio. Among the difficulties they have had in recent years is delinquency in the barrios of Managua. Neil is requesting a loan to buy more inventory and in this manner, to increase sales volume and generate more income, which will increase their business capital. This would permit the family to enjoy better conditions of life and solidity for future projects.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING PRODUCTS TO SELL

loans.name: Guillermina

texts.es:
Guillermina tiene 31 años, es casada, tiene tres hijos y pertenece al banco comunal “Las hijas de Maria” de la Asociación Arariwa. Guillermina se levanta muy temprano para hacer sus actividades del hogar como por ejemplo preparar desayuno para sus hijos y para hacer muchas cosas más. La socia se dedica a la venta de comida en el paradero final de los carros de la empresa de transportes “Tupac Amaru”. Ya son dos años que se dedica al negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo. Guillermina nos cuenta que requiere el préstamo para la matricula del colegio de sus hijos  y para comprar más insumos como arroz, verduras y carnes.

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma. La socia en la foto esta cargando a su hija Ruth de 6 meses de nacida.
texts.en:
Guillermina is 31 years old, married, and has 3 children. She belongs to the “Las Hijas de Maria” Communal Bank, of the Arariwa Association. Guillermina gets up very early to do her household chores, including preparing breakfast for the children, and many other things. She sells meals at the final bus stop of the Tupac Amaru transport enterprise. She has dedicated herself to this business for 2 years, and things have gone well, thanks to the effort she puts into her work. Guillermina needs a loan to pay her children's school fees, and to buy more business supplies, such as rice, vegetables and meat. She is grateful for the opportunity offered by this means and, also, she promises to meet the corresponding payment schedule. In the picture, she is carrying her 6-month-old daughter Ruth.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: PAYING HER CHILDREN'S SCHOOL FEES AND BUYING RICE, VEGETABLES, AND MEAT FOR HER BUSINESS

loans.name: Vilma

texts.es:
La señora Vilma es socia del Banco Comunal “Las Calceteras” desde hace 3 años, vive en el distrito de Juliaca, provincia de San Román y departamento de Puno, tiene 45 años de edad, es conviviente y tiene 05 hijos. Ella estudió primaria completa, se dedica a la compra y venta de oro.

Vilma nos cuenta que el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos, que fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, le sirvió para aumentar su capital.

Ella solicitará un crédito  de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles, con el cual podrá comprar oro y así obtener mayores ganancias.

Su sueño para el futuro es mejorar su negocio e incrementar su capital. 

Lo que más le gusta de su Banco Comunal son las reuniones y las charlas.
texts.en:
Mrs. Vilma is a member of the “Las Calceteras” Communal Bank for some 3 years; she lives in the district of Jualiaca, province of San Román, department of Puno. She is 45 years old, lives with her partner and has 5 children. She completed her primary school education and she now buys and sells gold.

Vilma tells us that that first loan that she received from Movimiento Manuela Ramos (Kiva’s field partner) was of S/. 300.00 nuevos soles and it helped her increase her working capital.

She needs a loan of S/. 500.00 nuevos soles to buy gold so that she can have greater income.

Her dream for the future is to improve her business and increase her profits.

What she enjoys most about her Communal Bank are the meetings and conversations with other members.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Duque, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy gold.

loans.name: Hermenegilda

texts.es:
La señora Hermenegilda es socia del Banco Comunal “Las Calceteras” desde hace 3 años, vive en el distrito de Juliaca, provincia de San Román y departamento de Puno, tiene 42 años de edad, está casada y tiene 03 hijos. Ella estudió hasta quinto de secundaria, se dedica a la venta de comida.

Hermenegilda nos cuenta que el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos, que fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, le sirvió para aumentar su capital.

Ella requiere un crédito  de S/. 1,000.00 nuevos soles, con el cual podrá comprar  arroz, papa, fideos, carne, verduras, etc.

Su sueño para el futuro es cambiar de negocio, quiere dedicarse a la compra y venta de ferretería. 

Lo que más le gusta de su Banco Comunal son los ahorros y las reuniones con las socias
texts.en:
Mrs. Hermenegilda is a member of the “Las Calceteras” Communal Bank for some 3 years, she lives in the in the district of Jualiaca, province of San Román, department of Puno. She is 42 years old, is married and has 3 children. She studied until the fifth year of secondary school and sells food.

Hermenegilda tells us that with the first loan that she received from Movimiento Manuela Ramos (Kiva’s field partner) was of S/. 300.00 nuevos soles and it helped her increase her working capital.

She needs a loan of S/. 1,000.00 nuevos soles and will use it to buy rice, potatoes, spaghetti, meat, vegetables, etc.

Her dream for the future is to change her business, she wants to buy and sell hardware.

What she enjoys most about her Communal Bank are the savings and the meetings with the other members.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Duque, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice, potatoes, spaghetti, meat, vegetables, etc.

loans.name: Luz Esther

texts.es: Luz Esther, es una mujer emprendedora, vive en el Distrito de Yarina cocha, región Ucayali, tiene 51 años, es madre de cuatro hijos y tres son todavía dependientes, ella se dedica a la venta de cervezas, golosinas y gaseosas, esta actividad la realiza en su casa, cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo que trabaja manejando su motocar. Luz Esther forma parte del Banco Comunal “Las Dinámicas”, desde hace 5 años, el primer crédito que recibió fue de 300 soles, que fue invertido en la compra de golosinas, ahora necesita un crédito de 800 soles, que será invertido en la compra de cerveza, gaseosas, golosinas y ropas usadas. La meta de Luz Esther es tener una fuente de soda-restaurant y crecer en su negocio de venta de ropas usadas.
texts.en:
Luz Esther is a very hardworking woman; she lives in the district of Yarina cocha, Ucayali region. She is 51 years old and is a mother to 4 children, 3 still depend on her economically, she sells beers, candy and refreshments, she does this at home and has the support of her husband who works driving a motorcycle taxi. Luz Esther is part of “Las Dinámicas” (The Dynamics) Communal Bank for some 5 years, the first loan that she received was of 300 soles, it was invested in candy, and she now needs a loan of 800 soles that will be invested to buy beer, refreshments, candy, and used clothing. Luz Esther’s goals are to have a soda fountain-restaurant and to see her business in used clothing grow.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Duque, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will use the loan to buy refreshments, candy, and used clothing.

loans.name: Ruth Lisseth

texts.es:
Ruth tiene 29 años, es soltera y pertenece al banco comunal “Las hijas de Maria” de la Asociación Arariwa. Ruth trabaja como docente desde hace 4 años en el colegio “Virgen de Fátima” en la ciudad del Cusco. La socia actualmente se encuentra preparándose para rendir el examen del Concurso Público de Contrato de Docente  2010. La socia nos cuenta que por las tardes hace reforzamientos de los cursos de matemáticas, ciencias lingüísticas, etc. a alumnos de bajo rendimiento escolar.  Ruth requiere el préstamo para la matricularse para poder rendir el examen del concurso público. 

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Ruth is 29 years old, she is single and belongs to the borrowing group "The Daughters of Maria" with Asociación Arariwa. Ruth has worked as a teacher for four years at the "Virgen of Fátima" high school in the city of Cusco. She is currently preparing to take the Public Teacher Contract exam for 2010. Ruth said that in the afternoons she tutors students who are behind in the subjects of mathmaticas, linguistic sciences, etc. Ruth needs this to be able to register for the exam. Ruth is grateful for the opportunity that this loan brings and is committed to complete her repayments according to the repayment plan.

Translated from Spanish by Kelly McKinnon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Ruth needs this loan to register for a teachers exam

loans.name: Maria Auxiladora

texts.es: Maria Auxiliadora tiene 66 años, su actividad económica es brindar el servicio de costura, este no es el primer financiamiento que solicita, pues han sido muy beneficiosos para su negocio. El financiamiento que solicita es para capital de trabajo que será utilizado para la compra de botones, telas, agujas, hilos entre otros productos. Ella quiere aprovechar esta temporada que es cuando los niños entran a clases y es la mejor oportunidad para realizar pedidos que ya le han encargo es por eso que solicita este financiamiento para la compra de materia prima. Su deseo es seguir con vida para continuar con este humilde trabajo.
texts.en:
Maria Auxiliadora is 66 years old, her economic activity is sewing; this is not her first loan since she has benefited a lot from the loans for her business. The loan will be used as work capital to buy buttons, fabrics, needles, threads among other products. She needs to take advantage of this season since this is when children go back to school and it is the best opportunity to complete all the work that has been commissioned, this is why she needs the loan to buy the materials. Her wish is remain alive to continue with this humble job.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Duque, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Work Capital.

loans.name: Greisy Pierina

texts.es:
Greisy Pierina, es una mujer jovial, vive en el Distrito de Calleria, región Ucayali, tiene 20 años, ella se dedica a la repostería, esta actividad la realiza en su casa  de donde posteriormente efectúa la entrega de pedidos a domicilio, es soltera. 
Greisy Pierina forma parte del Banco Comunal “Las triunfadoras”, desde hace 2 años, el primer crédito que recibió fue de 300 soles, que fue invertido en  la compra de implementos para repostería, ahora ella necesita un crédito de 700 soles para la compra de accesorios de repostería como son: piletas, armazones, muñecas. La meta de Greisy es ampliar su negocio y tener su microempresa de pasteles y tortas.
texts.en:
Greisy Pierina is a cheerful woman who lives in the Calleria district of the Ucayali Region. She is 20 years old and single. Her work is making cakes, which she prepares at her own house and then delivers to her customers' homes. Greisy Pierina has been a member of the "Las Triunfadoras” ("The Winners") communal bank for the past two years. The first loan she received was for 300 Peruvian soles, which she invested in accessories for cake making. She now needs a loan of 700 soles to purchase cake-making accessories such as pans, frames and figurines. Greisy's goal is to expand her business and operate a microenterprise making various kinds of cakes.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing accessories for cake making such as pans, frames and figurines

loans.name: Ana Patricia

texts.es: Patricia tiene 35 años de edad, vive con su esposo y sus hijos de 8 años de edades ella tiene su negocio de confeccion de trajes. Hace 5 años empezó su negocio en su casa, es un negocio formal entrega su mercadería en tiendas en distintos municipios y departamentos. Patricia también atiende en su negocio de tienda de consumo diario esta muy contenta porque le ha ido muy bien ella solicita su crédito para abrir un local en su casa para incrementar su mercadería
texts.en:
Patricia, 35, lives with her husband and her eight year old children. She has a business making outfits. She started the business in her house five years ago. It is a dependable business. She delivers her merchandise to stores in different municipalities and departments. Patricia also takes care of her store, which carries daily consumption products.
